number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This is possibly the best Kart racer I have ever played.  Having grown up as a SEGA fanboy, this is the SEGA answer to Mario Kart that I always wanted and the PC version definitely gives Mario Kart 8 a run for its money! It's also a great livingroom PC/HTPC game, as it supports up to 4 players on a single screen (local splitscreen.)The tracks are varied and well designed, with plenty of shortcuts and bonuses which reward skilled players.  Being a huge SEGA fan from back in the day, I really appreciated the call-backs and themes the levels offered (Golden Axe, Shinobi, Skies of Arcadia, and more!)As far as difficulty is concerned, this game is no cakewalk.  There is a learning curve involved in teaching yourself how to drift, how to boost, and how to stack boosts in order to be competitive, but the game greatly rewards you for building your skill.  Beware: The A.I is absolutely cutthroat and they won't show you any mercy while you're still getting used to things.  While at first they seem to be absolutely unfair, they can be overcome with practice and skill as well as knowledge of the track.  They do not rubber-band to the player like Mario Kart's opponents do in older entries.  There are items which you can use to attack/sabotage other drivers just like in Mario Kart, however they play less of an important role in SASRT, as you will not find yourself getting item-spammed at inopportune times if you're good enough to get ahead of the pack.The tracks themselves can change lap-to-lap and new situations may require a new type of vehicle.  That's where the "transformed" part of the game's name comes in.  Each vehicle is capable of transforming from a car to a boat to a plane and back again, depending on the level's terrain.  The transformations are automatic (so you don't have to worry about having the wrong vehicle type at the wrong time) and they add a great variety to the overall gameplay.  There is a learning curve involved in learning the different handling of each vehicle type (especially the planes), but they are not difficult to get a hang of.Each character has unique stats and abilities and they can be leveled up through racing and completing events/challenges.  When leveling up, you can unlock 'mods' which drastically alter your character's stats and can be helpful on certain courses (for example, the handling mod will boost cart handling and can help on an icy stage with lots of turns.)Another huge advantage that this game has over Mario Kart is its Single Player campaign.  While Mario Kart only really offers a Grand Prix and Time Trial mode for its single player experience, SASRT offers both of those plus a "World Tour" mode in which players must complete a wide variety of events (races, drift challenges, boost challenges, combat race challenges, etc) to earn stars which can be used to unlock additional characters as well as stat/kart upgrades.  If you want, you can even play local multiplayer in World Tour mode (up to 4 players) and everyone can take on the challenge simultaneously. I found that I got a good 30 hours of gameplay out of World Tour so far and I haven't even 100% finished it yet; there's lots of content to be had!I highly recommend this game to any fans of racers, Sonic, and SEGA franchises of old.  You won't find a better Mario Kart alternative on PC (short of emulation.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
A wonderful game that pays tribute to everything Sega, Sonic and All-Stars Racing Transformed is something that will crush the competition for years to come.The Good:Level Design and Diversity: S&ART's levels come in many different shapes and sizes, and all of them provide a rich, detailed and fun experience for the players. From challenging levels make Rainbow Road look easy to wonderfuly crafted thematic levels such as  Dream Valley, S&ART has a level for every skill level. Character Diversity: Every vehicle and level in S&ART has it's unique style and feel and style. From General Winter's Tank to Shogun's wooden... Chariot, The level of character diversity in S&ART easily surpasses the majority of arcade racing games on the market.The Notable:The Boats and Planes: The addition of boats and planes has opened up many unique opportunies for fun and often whacky levels. However, this is no Skydrift or Hydro Thunder. The boats often feel slow and clunky, and the feeling of being in water is only kept there by the predictable wave effects. The planes are meant to be the fastest and most agile of the vehicles, and yet they feel very bloated and dance through the sky instead of cutting through the air. Drifting is also a very gimicked function on these two modes, and serves as a tie-in feature to keep the feel of the game consistent. Modes that aren't Racing: From 'Capture the Chao' to 'Battle Arena', secondary modes serve as mostly a distraction (albeit an intresting and somewhat fun one) from the core of the game. The fun that one may have is generally very inconsistent as these modes generally rely on utilising one feature of the game over and over again. The Bad:Poorly designed PC Menus: Graphical customisation cannot be done in game, it must be instead configured through an external menu. The placement of the menu items in game are also have a 'console port' feel, with clunky selection menus and awkwardly placed buttons.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed completely outclasses its predecessor, Sonic & SEGA All-Stars Racing, in every way. This game is amazing, and playing split-screen or online multiplayer with friends is a lot of fun. The character selection, course design and gameplay are some of the best in the genre, and the soundtrack is an absolutely incredible selection of remixed classic tunes, to which you can credit Richard Jacques, also known for his work on Sonic R, Sonic 3D Blast Saturn and Metropolis Street Racer, among many other things.And it's not just a straight console port either! In fact, while this game is great on X360, PS3 and Wii U, the PC version is the definitive version, offering improved textures, resolution and is the only version capable of running in 60fps. The PC exclusive characters leave a lot to be desired though, but their presence doesn't retroactively ruin the game. They're just not a deal-maker over the console editions.If you're sick of Mario Kart, then this is the best Mario Kart killer since Crash Team Racing. It's a game that is truly full of surprises.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												It had been a long time since I last played a good old racing kart game, and suddenly this game appeared before my eyes on Steam. By looking at some videos of the gameplay and reading some of the positive reviews I decided to give it a shot, and boy did I become a fan real quick! I have always liked kart games like these for their beautiful colors, goofy characters and creative weapons and this game nails those spots right on!With beloved characters from the SEGA universe and some newcomers, this game offers a real nice variation of vehicles along with awesome and unique All-Star moves to go along with which lets you choose your way to devastate the track when you're having a bad day and watch you fly right past the competition in an awesome spectacle, may it be by the usage of rockets, soundwaves or bananas. The creative weapons are both amusing and rediculous and makes the races go completely out of control which is one of the charms of kart games like these. You can also find the usual powerups which lets you boost up to higher speeds or block incoming attacks, but with all the crazy weapons and powerups aside, this game can really offer you a test of racing skill to see if you got what it takes to go even faster by using risky air-stunts and powerful drift-boosts which, altough makes the game a little more difficult, also makes the game more thrilling and exciting and overall more fun. The race tracks are, what you would expect, tracks based on several of the SEGA character's original titles which definitely is a must for party games like these, and putting the "Transformed" in this game's title is the fact that in most of the stages there is a transition to race by both boat and plane during the race which puts more variety and challenge into the game.So if you're a fan of racing games with elements of driving by car, boat and plane as well as neat combos you can pull off, or even if you're just a fan of Sonic and his friends I truly recommend and tell you that this game is for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Sega, a company who live mostly in our memories. When it comes to talking about our favorite Sega games, you'd be hard pressed to name one game that was released in the past decade. As a test, i asked a few of my friends on Steam what their favorite Sega game of all time is.My best friend said "Sonic 3", Streets Of Rage 2 was another game mentioned by a few of my Steam acquaintance as well as Shenmue, but nothing from the past 10 years.Just to give some insight into my history as a gamer, i grew up as a Nintendo gamer. My first console was an NES which i got for Christmas 1991, so it's fair to say, i was a Mario fan from day one.The playground debate over who is better out of Mario and Sonic was always a no brainer to me, because as much as i loved Sonic The Hedgehog (and i did), Super Mario 3 was the game that blew everything else away and completely obliterated the competition.Yes...you couldn't go far wrong with Mario. From 8 bit to 16 bit, from 16 bit to 64 bit, from 64 bit to 128 bit, Nintnedo always seemed to know what direction push Mario in, but with the success of 3D Mario games came similar attempts at 3D adventure games from other companies trying to achieve the same levels of success.Introducing Sonic Adventure, The Dreamcasts answer to Mario 64. The first thing i ever saw of Sonic Adventure was a screen shot in a games magazine, and it blew me away. The graphics looked phenominal and i remember thinking if Sega manages to transfer the same gameplay from 2D Sonic games into 3D, this might be a Mario 64 killer....but little did i know, it would be the start of Segas downfall.In present day 2016, attempts at recreating the Sonic franchise have been many. 3 Sonic Adventure games, Shadow The Hedgehog, Sonic Riders, Sonic And The Secret Rings, Sonic Rivals, Sonic And The Black Knight, Sonic Colours, Sonic Generations......the list goes on, and only sequels to the megadrive series of Sonic games captured a majority of peoples imaginations.With this in mind, I approach every Sonic game with an equal amount of skepticism and trepidation, but when i noticed Sonic & All Stars Racing Transformed in a Steam sale, my curiosity got the better of me...and i'm pleased to say, i'm glad it did.You may be wondering "why begin a review of a Sonic game with a whole spiel about Nintnedo", and this is why. Sonic & All Stars Racing Transformed is a Mario Kart killer!. Yes, despite the fact Mario Kart games are rated higher and have a wider fan base, i can't help but feel Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed fell victim to the sour taste left in peoples mouths whenever the name "Sonic" is mentioned. According to my Steam account, i have put 22 hours into Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed. In which time i have 100 percented it, something i never feel an incentive to do when playing a racing game, however, this game is so fun, i didnt want to leave any of it unexplored.Just to state a few reasons why i believe this game is a Mario Kart killer, firstly the track design. Where Mario Kart suffers from repetetive courses that stay the same, courses in Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed changed depending what lap you're on. The first lap might be land based on four wheels, 2nd lap on water and 3rd in the air. Your vehicle transforms to accomodate changes in terrain and is done automatically and with such fluidity that it dosnt distract from what is a consistently smooth exoerience throughout.The power ups are far more balanced and you don't often find yourself dropping from 1st place position to 8th in the blink of an eye just because someone decided to pull a blue shell from their back side.Those are just 2 points which i believe to be factually better than what Mario Kart offers. There are many more aspects of Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed which i prefer to Mario Kart, but these are all matters of preference that i don't feel the need to mention, mostly aesthetics and other opinion based aspects.To end this review, i'd just like to say i have over 150 games in my Steam library ranging from RTS to RPGs, from First Person Shooters to Point and Clicks, from Racing games to beat em ups, and Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is the most fun iv'e had thus far.95%

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is a solid addition to the "Kart Racing" genre. I put kart in quotes because there are no karts in this game. What there are instead are some pretty solid cars, planes and boats that all control and handle how they should do. In this game I never find myself annoyed at the game for how it plays, if something goes wrong usually it's my fault.I also like the difficulty in this game as well, it's not a "cheap" difficulty where you are bombarded with special items left right and centre, no. Oponents actually drive pretty well and don't seem to follow a set path but rather make decisions to throw you off.Is this game just another Mario Kart clone? Far from it, it's not even in the same league. I would play this over Mario Kart any day.The music, by English composer Richard Jaques, is pretty damn good. With remixes of some classic Sega tunes and some pretty good original compositions you really cannot go wrong with it. And yes, this is the same man that did the Catchphrase theme song (didn't go where you thought it would did you?)If I did have one complaint however (and this one works in MKs favour) the courses can be very long, almost too long so if you haven't got much time to play a game, this isn't the game for you.  Section Out of 10   Graphics 8   Music 8   Gameplay 9   Total 8.5

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Awesome. 9/10Nostalgic & classic, yet also very competitive, challenging and has incorporated diverse styles of gameplay within the races. This game is controller friendly and fun for pretty much anybody wanting to have a casual jam session. Great for multiplayer/online gameplay.The different race tracks are beautifully structured and the classic iconic characters fit the themes of their cars so well. The interace has a really classic arcade layout but the frames are well polished. I love the graphics... I don't know how some people could complain about them. This isn't meant to be a realistic driving simulator, it's an SEGA-themed arcade racing game.The composition is a masterpiece. I love the textures and rich lighting that give the game a warm, vibrant and fast paced racing environment.I never thought I would find so much joy in what originally appeared to be too 'childish' for a grown man to play but the game is just awesome. I hope that other manly men with beards still feel manly after playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												A surprisingly coherent racing experience. The AI is genuinely challenging (and not in the typical racing rubberbanding kind of way) and playing online against others is legitimately fun, even when you lose. If you're a fan of Sega franchises and characters, you'll find that you'll likely have one or two characters you'll enjoy racing as. There's even a handful of third party characters that were all crossover promotions. The differences between the characters are all pretty subtle, and the modifications offer a great way to adjust your favorite character(s) to be more in line with your playstyle. Some of the picks for characters are odd (Danica Patrick?) and others are clever.The tracks themselves are interesting, all based on Sega franchises. Unsurprisingly, there's a ton of Sonic-related levels, but lots of other franchises get representation in stage form, as well.My only gripes with the game comes with the learning curve. You'll find that after two or three races, driving and boating sections will become second nature, and it'll take a few more races to learn tricks. The problem comes when you first encounter a track with flying elements. Probably the worst sections of the game, I dread when tracks are chosen that focus on flying because it's clearly the section of the game that was worked on the least, and should have been left out of the game. My guess was that they wanted to go for a Diddy Kong Racing dynamic with this one and couldn't leave flying out. It would have been a far, FAR better game without it.The other modes that aren't racing are half-baked at best and completely unenjoyable at worst. The game's engine is clearly not made for anything other than actual racing, and it shows when you play battle modes or Capture the Chao. You'll want to steer clear of those game modes completely and focus on just racing.Otherwise, the game is a coherent racing experience and is legitimately enjoyable. It's fast paced, and the weapons are fairly easy to utilize (though some require a bit of skill to use effectively). The sense of speed on some tracks is fairly exciting, and it's possible to boost almost constantly on a number of tracks, rewarding skilled players but offering a learning challenge to new players. Highly recommended to support this game in hopes of a sequel that removes the flying aspects.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Quick factsGood+ Solid port that runs well on many systems and looks good (tip downscale from 4k for better results if your hardware can handle it).+ Customize the stats of your driver to your liking with mods that you unlock just playing as them.+ Responsive controls that reward drifts and air tricks accordingly.+ Good soundtrack with tunes from some of Sega best games.+ Dificulty options for new players and experienced kart game players.+ Multiplayer local play with special mention to the option of the possibility to play the entire campaign cooperatively.+ Online multiplayer modes for up to 10 players per event.* Full Xbox 360 controller support with rumble.Bad- A little barren online community (nowadays)- Some bugs here and there (mostly in the track physics)- Generic items and some derivative courses.- Some form of balance issues.- Ommision of some other good franchises from Sega.One of the best "karting" games that exists on PC, and one of the select few that give the Mario Kart series a run for it´s money. The gameplay mechanics reward skill and dedication, even giving the players the options to choose his real favorite character and choosing determined stat presets to set it at their preferred style. The method of controlling your vehicle is a little loose, and the physics act a little wacky from time to time, something that can bother the way up to the podium in the S class difficulty. Also, the online mode doesn´t get many players nowadays, so it´s more likely you end playing only with your friendsGood variation of tracks from classic jewels from Sega like Panzer Dragoon or Burning Rangers, and   the soundtrack sports some great tunes from After Burner, Shinobi and more. Not as stellar as the soundtrack, the item selection is one of the most boring i have seen in a game, but well it´s not THAT broken, like the infamous Mario Kart blue shell. The game is well suited for new and veteran players alike, and more enjoyable with a controller. Solid choice for playing in local mode with splitscreen for up to 4 players.

												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is THE kart racing game on PC. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I know what people normally do with this game, which is compare with Mario Kart... Which they have very close features, but this game deserves to be tested and felt on its own. So... forget any previous MK experience and give this game a try!I've bought this game while on sale, so it was very cheap. And I have no regrets! This game really drove me nuts trying to perfect my drifting skills.Unlikely any normal go-kart arcade game, this game actually benefits from some real racing techiques like following the corners apex to get the fastest lines like no other arcade game I've played so far. That really made me happy, since I'm a huge fan of sim racing style gaming, and for a 'just for fun experience' kind of game, this really made a fusion of what I like on a sim racing game and the fun chaos of an arcade game.But, that doesn't mean you need to have any kind of experience in sim racings to have fun in this game. It's just that to get to a perfection (Specially trying to beat the devs fastest laps on each circuit), it's something to be considered.Some pros and cons that I really would like to show:Pros:- Really fun go-kart/arcade racing game. Easy to get into, hard to master.- Power-ups that range from a homing rocket, to a Super Star item which makes you invincible and can change the race results at any time.- Very good sense of speed and physics.- Stunt/Drift techniques that gives you boost.- Some tracks completely change from one lap to another, which makes each lap a unique experience.- Different kind of vehicles at different sections of the race (Car, Boat and Plane).- Very good amount of tracks to choose from. (Not too many, but not too few)- Great host of drivers to choose from, each with their own ups and downs, all from different SEGA Games.- Great soundtrack!- Very nice visuals.- Several different game modes which changes completely the way you play.- Lots of unlockables.Cons:- A Little bit tricky to learn the controls at the beginning (Specially when flying).- Some cars are better at some tracks than others.- Online multiplayer is a little bit weird. Sometimes you finish a race, but it doesn't actually finish the race. On server side, your character gets stuck somewhere and you dont get to finish the race.- Sometimes the stunts don't work and try to compensate in the next trick, which results in 'Stunt Failed' and boost loss.Overall, this game is a really fun experience, wether your looking for a fun time playing with your friends, alone or online, or trying to master all the tracks shortcuts and routes.Definitely a must buy if you're an arcade racing game fan!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is the best kart racer you can get right now. I find the controls and physics in this game make much more sense than the most recent Mario Kart, for example. If you remember playing Diddy Kong Racing for the Nintendo 64, this game feels very much like a spiritual successor (in the best way).Pros:- Excellent single-player mode with a variety of events (races, drift challenges, and more)- Local co-op for the single-player mode where secondary players and easily join/drop-out between any event- Game rewards you for taking risks and drifting- Game controls are easy to understand but can take some time to master (drifting feels really great)- Tracks are varied, fun and interesting to play, and each has an excellent music trackCons:- Infrequent glitching in particular walls and aerial obsticles such that they can sometimes be quite punishing if you hit them- Playing as a slow character lowers the speed of opponent racers (NPCs) in single-player9/10 - The flaws are minimal and become non-issues as you will need to be very good to beat the game on max difficulty anyway. This game checks all the right boxes (amazing soundtrack, great gameplay, replayability)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												I usually don't like racing games but this... this is addicting.I mean it's so fun, I don't know half of these guys because I'm not a Sonic/Sega fan but they do seem a charismatic and diverse bunch!The items are straightforward and there aren't much of them, but they're different and easy to use after some practice.The driving requires a good amount of skill between drifting, acrobatics and other stuff that helps you boost your speed.All in all, it's easy to learn, but hard to master.I like the fact that your "car" or kart becomes a boat or even a flying jet (!) in certain areas and it's a totally different feeling, like, flying is not a dumbed down version of a car, you go up down whenever you like and the boat is hard to maneuver.I've been having TONS of fun with this battling against friends online or inviting guests like my girlfriend, plugging 2 controllers and playing, you can even combine controllers + keyboard and then go to an online match!Overall, as a guy that doesn't like racing games, I loved this one, probably the first and the last, recommended for parties at your house or just plain fun.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												A lot of people think this game is just a copy of Mario Kart 7, due to the flying and boat transformations. However, alot of people don't know that Sega had the Idea first. I bought the original game on my DS. Not very good graphics or gameplay. Then I saw this game on sale, and I couldn't stop myself from buying it, as well as a little bit of DLC. This game is amazing. 10/10. The graphics have improved, though that may just be my opinion because of the DS' graphics. The gameplay is better than Mario Kart. In Mario Kart 7, during the flying sections, you don't feel much control. Sonic & All-Stars Racing: Transformed fixes that. At first I didn't realize I had much power over flying, so I ended up in last place. I even had the game turn on Y-axis. Also the game's cast of characters are great. Wreck It Ralph, Yogscast, Pyro, Heavy, and Spy all make appearances. Well, Pyro, Heavy, and Spy make up one team called Team Fortess, so, does that still count? I'm saying yes. Anyways, if this game wasn't on sale I probably wouldn't even try it. But, I ended up loving it. Man, I love this game.

												I'll do a legit review now. Okay so I have this game on PS3, Vita, on my 5S, and used to have it on 3DS. Still haven't gotten tired of this game after a year and a half of playing. On PC theres more characters than the other versions plus it plays at 60 FPS (if you have the hardware)Mechanics are solid, physics OCCASIONALLY get outta whack. Great variety in the tracks too. 10 player online races and battles. World Tour, GP, Time Trials and Single Races are the modes made up for single player. World Tour is basically a mission mode with missions like beat the ghosts time, or avoid traffic, or boost races which are races without power ups but boosts are spammed on the track, battle races give you 3 lives and you race for 1st place unless you eliminate everyone on the track with power ups.Highly reccomend this

I definitely can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												What at first seems like a poor man's Mario Kart turns out to be one of the largest, most polished, and, most importantly, balanced, kart racers ever made. There's no rubber band AI or Blue Shells here, the majority of races are won with one thing and one thing alone: skill. Sure, items can help or hinder your position, but they'll never be a complete game changer. Topped off with gorgeous courses, a soundtrack composed of both original pieces and remixed ones, and plenty of content, All-Stars Racing Transformed is incredibly fun and sure to keep you racing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
http://clickbliss.net/post/92637780532/why-i-love-sonic-all-stars-racing-transformed"Sumo Digital have obviously learned something from their time working on the Outrun series, because this has some of the best feeling drift mechanics since the 2006 entry. Essentially a Mario Kart style powerslide mechanic, All Stars simplifies it to a single button press and demands that you master it to properly navigate the course. Basically if you’re not drifting at every opportunity you're doing it wrong. Seriously, the drifts in this game put Initial D to shame. Also, you can drift in a plane. All Stars manages to one up Mario Kart as well by actually being fair. While there are a mass of powerups, each one of them can be countered or avoided with skill, removing the slot machine 8th to 1st overtakes of the Mario Kart series. It also means brutal online competition. Seriously, if you think you can drive just wait until you see the online community. "

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Easily one of the best racing games I've played, not just kart racing! While preventing the alienation of more casual players, the game manages to take the actual racing very seriously. There is an unusually high level of skill required to win in hard mode. It encourages that you learn the tracks and how to navigate them with effecient boosting, or you lose; I personally really enjoyed this!Racing against other experienced players, the items are very fun and I never felt cheated by them! All races can be won by pure skill alone; luck plays a rare factor. This is a welcome change from other popular kart racers, where victory can be determined by fire-and-forget homing attacks that cannot be prevented. Certain items in this game can even be avoided with a well timed boost, air dodge, or obstruction.Many of the stages are way better looking than I'd expect for a game of this type. There is a high level of artistry and aesthetic awareness all throughout. It looks truly fantastic at times!This is easily one of my favorite games graphically and it doesn't hurt it's a tremendous amount of fun to play! I recommend this to anyone who enjoys balanced and atypical racing.I like this game so much, I bought it for: myself, my ex, a friend, and repurchased it once it was released on PC. That should either be a testament to how great this game is, or how poorly I manage my money.The game has also been so cheap as of late, I would simply buy it to experience the visuals alone!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												When you first look at Sonic all stars racing transformed, it seems like nothing more than a generic kart racer staring sonic.  However if you dig deep enough you'll find a much more complex racing system than in most other racing game.  First of all in addition to the karts you also have access to boats and planes for all characters.  This is where the games design shines as often you'll get multiple options of where to go, one where you take the high road in the skies and the other plodding on the ground or in a boat.  Another nice thing is the items which are only there to spice the game up rather than giving sucky players an unfair advantage.  Even the all star move is balanced in a way that it only really helps if you know how to use it.  The game looks amazing when running at max settings though I've noticed some significant issues with fps even when at minimal settings(Though this may just be my computer.  The game does have it's flaws, characters aren't varried that much especially since all star moves are so much more bland compared to the first game, and the leveling up system is dull and tedious beyond words.  Also I highly reccomend you play this using a controller only as playing with the mouse and keyboard sucks so much its not even worth trying.  But this is the definitive version of All stars transformed as it has additional characters with more promised while the console ports are left in the dust.  And since this game has gone on sale a couple of times since it's release there's little excuse not to pick it up.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												I'm an N64 kart racer veteran (MK64, DKR, Lego Racers, Penny Racers, etc.), and I daresay this is as good (if not better than) any N64 kart racer I've ever played. Unlike some other games that use rubber bands, you need skill here. The variety of characters, mods, and tracks is above average for this type of game. I've mainly stuck to single-player so far, but it's been a blast. Online play works fine (but I don't have many friends with this game) and split-screen is available, but single player alone is addictive enough that I think I goofed up my trigger finger and damaged my eyes a bit.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed for PC is the perfect alternative to Mario Kart of a fun and whacky racing party game, if you don't own a Nintendo console.As a racing game it doesn't have the deepest mechanics, but drifting, braking and reward for skill are all there, so there's nothing to dislike. As a racing party game, it has tons of content! Customization, varied characters, stages and fun powerups... everything you want to have fun with your friends. Online play and a lot of singleplayer content make it a good singleplayer experience.It's graphics are not super great though, but they do the job. It's music is a good selection although it isn't the catchiest. The selection of characters and stages though are kind of... ackward. Ignoring the fact that Wreck-It Ralph, Danica Patrick and Team Fortress are even in this game, the selection of characters from SEGA titles in the end seem weird and don't work all that well together. In comparision to Smash Bros. where all characters fit really well together, this game as a wide and weird array of characters that don't really match. Still, the ammount of SEGA representation is here including Amigo, NiGHTS and tons of Sonic characters, as you'd expect.The system of the track changing and the cars trasforming to planes and boats really is the mechanic that makes this game really stand out. Each vehicle has different yet similar mechanics making it so it's easy and simple for the player to change control schemes, while still making it varied. That being said, perhaps it's a little too similar since the tracks are always the same and the vehicles transform in select sections make it so that it really blends in to the game too much, making this unique mechanic not stand out as much. What I mean is that the tracks don't really take too much advantage of the three forms and doesn't unlock its true potential. You don't have a option most of the time to choose if you take a shortcut for the car or a vertical shorcut with the plane. It's always the same and there isn't too much freedom to transform. Still, it's a pretty neat mechanic and is worth checking out on its own.Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is perfect if you want a racing party game but you don't own a Nintendo console and it's worth checking out even on its own. It's a fun game for sure, but it's not groundbreaking and is not a real replacement to other party games since it's a PC game.Worth checking out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
A great kart racing gameIt plays great. You feel a sense of speed and performing drifts and tricks is fun. I have a feeling that some of the people that worked on this game also worked on F-Zero GX. Compared to Mario Kart Wii, the cars control better. (I haven't played Mario Kart 8.)But it has some flaws. The menu has an very annoying announcer, the power-ups aren't that good and the music is not memorable. And although I did say it plays great, the physics can be weird sometimes and the track design questionable. Sometimes a small mistake can mean coming to a full stop and finishing the race close to last.This game can be hard. But in my opinion, that's what makes it great. And to add variety, you also race by airplane and by boat, with the tracks often transforming themselves, It will keep you on your toes.People will instinctively compare this game to Mario Kart. But it's closer to F-Zero and Diddy Kong Racing in terms of gameplay. And that's OK with me.If you're looking for a kart racing game to add to your Steam collection, this is the one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Sonic : All Stars Racing Transformed is a fantastic take on the arcade racing genre boasting heaps of content and replay-abilty value as well as full controller support for those using game-pads.The maps are both visually and technically beautiful, equipped with dozens of tracks varying in difficultly from simple to advanced providing a user friendly experience for new players. The Transformation mechanics adding new layers to the game, providing the player with the responsibility of learning boat's, planes and cars all handling extremely different yet somehow remaining intuitive making the game that much more entertaining.The game is equipped with a single player career mode as well as a fully-fleshed out matchmaking system. Overall this game is a beautifully fresh take on arcade-racers and I have no doubt future games will be referencing it for years to come as the genre diversifies.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												When I first saw Reddit singing songs of praise for Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed I was skeptical at best. After 21 hours of play time I can say the praise is well deserved. The carts are varied and customisable (leveling up the carts will eventually give you 7 stats mods variants to choose from). Boosting/power sliding is tight and responsive and tracks range from standard cart racing to a mixture land, sea and air which you switch between on the fly.With a roster of 29 characters, the option of 4 player local split screen and full controller support Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed really does hold its own in the cart racing genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is a solid addition to the "Kart Racing" genre. I put kart in quotes because there are no karts in this game. What there are instead are some pretty solid cars, planes and boats that all control and handle how they should do. In this game I never find myself annoyed at the game for how it plays, if something goes wrong usually it's my fault.I also like the difficulty in this game as well, it's not a "cheap" difficulty where you are bombarded with special items left right and centre, no. Oponents actually drive pretty well and don't seem to follow a set path but rather make decisions to throw you off.Is this game just another Mario Kart clone? Far from it, it's not even in the same league. I would play this over Mario Kart any day.The music, by English composer Richard Jaques, is pretty damn good. With remixes of some classic Sega tunes and some pretty good original compositions you really cannot go wrong with it. And yes, this is the same man that did the Catchphrase theme song (didn't go where you thought it would did you?)If I did have one complaint however (and this one works in MKs favour) the courses can be very long, almost too long so if you haven't got much time to play a game, this isn't the game for you.  Section Out of 10   Graphics 8   Music 8   Gameplay 9   Total 8.5

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Easily one of the best racing games I've played, not just kart racing! While preventing the alienation of more casual players, the game manages to take the actual racing very seriously. There is an unusually high level of skill required to win in hard mode. It encourages that you learn the tracks and how to navigate them with effecient boosting, or you lose; I personally really enjoyed this!Racing against other experienced players, the items are very fun and I never felt cheated by them! All races can be won by pure skill alone; luck plays a rare factor. This is a welcome change from other popular kart racers, where victory can be determined by fire-and-forget homing attacks that cannot be prevented. Certain items in this game can even be avoided with a well timed boost, air dodge, or obstruction.Many of the stages are way better looking than I'd expect for a game of this type. There is a high level of artistry and aesthetic awareness all throughout. It looks truly fantastic at times!This is easily one of my favorite games graphically and it doesn't hurt it's a tremendous amount of fun to play! I recommend this to anyone who enjoys balanced and atypical racing.I like this game so much, I bought it for: myself, my ex, a friend, and repurchased it once it was released on PC. That should either be a testament to how great this game is, or how poorly I manage my money.The game has also been so cheap as of late, I would simply buy it to experience the visuals alone!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
http://clickbliss.net/post/92637780532/why-i-love-sonic-all-stars-racing-transformed"Sumo Digital have obviously learned something from their time working on the Outrun series, because this has some of the best feeling drift mechanics since the 2006 entry. Essentially a Mario Kart style powerslide mechanic, All Stars simplifies it to a single button press and demands that you master it to properly navigate the course. Basically if you’re not drifting at every opportunity you're doing it wrong. Seriously, the drifts in this game put Initial D to shame. Also, you can drift in a plane. All Stars manages to one up Mario Kart as well by actually being fair. While there are a mass of powerups, each one of them can be countered or avoided with skill, removing the slot machine 8th to 1st overtakes of the Mario Kart series. It also means brutal online competition. Seriously, if you think you can drive just wait until you see the online community. "

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a lot of fun and really improves on its predecessor. The gameplay is smooth and responsive and the races feel action packed. There is a large variety of weapons to thwart your competition and a good variety of brilliantly designed courses. The courses never get boring because a number of them alternate between being ground based, water based and aviation based depending on the lap or course you are on. Different characters start off with and transform into different vehicles suited to the type of race. Each individual character also earns different 'mods' for their vehicles when they level up which alter their stats.  The announcer from the previous game is no longer in it and instead it is just spectated when you are "owning the race" or have performed a stunt or attack. The soundtrack is as good and as fitting  as ever with some really well done remixes. You can play with up to four players but playing against the AI also offers up a worthy challenge depending on the chosen difficulty. Playing on a higher difficulty rewards you with more stars which are used to unlock more characters, courses and bonuses.The are only two things that grate on me about this game, one being the inclusion of characters that just don't seem to fit such as 'Danica Patrick' who appeared in the game because she was sponsored by Sega. In my opinion it would have been better to include some more well known characters such as Kazuma from the Yakuza series which was by Sega. On the upside there were a few DLC characters that were added for free. The final annoyance is that I have found the game sometimes crashes to desktop for no apparent reason. This is no reason to not buy the game (because it is a justified purchase that offers a shed load of fun) but it can induce some serious rage when you're in the middle of a race or have just set up a multiplayer session.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is the best kart racer you can get right now. I find the controls and physics in this game make much more sense than the most recent Mario Kart, for example. If you remember playing Diddy Kong Racing for the Nintendo 64, this game feels very much like a spiritual successor (in the best way).Pros:- Excellent single-player mode with a variety of events (races, drift challenges, and more)- Local co-op for the single-player mode where secondary players and easily join/drop-out between any event- Game rewards you for taking risks and drifting- Game controls are easy to understand but can take some time to master (drifting feels really great)- Tracks are varied, fun and interesting to play, and each has an excellent music trackCons:- Infrequent glitching in particular walls and aerial obsticles such that they can sometimes be quite punishing if you hit them- Playing as a slow character lowers the speed of opponent racers (NPCs) in single-player9/10 - The flaws are minimal and become non-issues as you will need to be very good to beat the game on max difficulty anyway. This game checks all the right boxes (amazing soundtrack, great gameplay, replayability)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I know what people normally do with this game, which is compare with Mario Kart... Which they have very close features, but this game deserves to be tested and felt on its own. So... forget any previous MK experience and give this game a try!I've bought this game while on sale, so it was very cheap. And I have no regrets! This game really drove me nuts trying to perfect my drifting skills.Unlikely any normal go-kart arcade game, this game actually benefits from some real racing techiques like following the corners apex to get the fastest lines like no other arcade game I've played so far. That really made me happy, since I'm a huge fan of sim racing style gaming, and for a 'just for fun experience' kind of game, this really made a fusion of what I like on a sim racing game and the fun chaos of an arcade game.But, that doesn't mean you need to have any kind of experience in sim racings to have fun in this game. It's just that to get to a perfection (Specially trying to beat the devs fastest laps on each circuit), it's something to be considered.Some pros and cons that I really would like to show:Pros:- Really fun go-kart/arcade racing game. Easy to get into, hard to master.- Power-ups that range from a homing rocket, to a Super Star item which makes you invincible and can change the race results at any time.- Very good sense of speed and physics.- Stunt/Drift techniques that gives you boost.- Some tracks completely change from one lap to another, which makes each lap a unique experience.- Different kind of vehicles at different sections of the race (Car, Boat and Plane).- Very good amount of tracks to choose from. (Not too many, but not too few)- Great host of drivers to choose from, each with their own ups and downs, all from different SEGA Games.- Great soundtrack!- Very nice visuals.- Several different game modes which changes completely the way you play.- Lots of unlockables.Cons:- A Little bit tricky to learn the controls at the beginning (Specially when flying).- Some cars are better at some tracks than others.- Online multiplayer is a little bit weird. Sometimes you finish a race, but it doesn't actually finish the race. On server side, your character gets stuck somewhere and you dont get to finish the race.- Sometimes the stunts don't work and try to compensate in the next trick, which results in 'Stunt Failed' and boost loss.Overall, this game is a really fun experience, wether your looking for a fun time playing with your friends, alone or online, or trying to master all the tracks shortcuts and routes.Definitely a must buy if you're an arcade racing game fan!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												So, when Sonic & All-Stars Racing first came out, everyone pretty much just passed it off as a Mario Kart clone that would never quite make it. But, with this installment, it blows that idea out of the water. This is better than Mario Kart. While it has less in the way of more well-known characters and wacky items, it has its own charm with nostalgic favourites like Beat and Ulala from Sega's classics; alongside representatives from their newer IPs; all the while revelling in cheesy dialogue from them all and a range of dynamic, stunning tracks to race around. It doesn't try to be something so much greater than Mario Kart or similar family racing games; but pulls it off anyway - it's just wild and fun, The fact that rubber-banding effects are really lessened in this game is particularly welcome, although it still has its own type - the All-Star moves; although they are fun in their own way.All in all, highly recommended for anyone who's getting a bit old for Mario Kart or just wants to try something new.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Yes, Mario Kart clones come and go but Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed (phew!) stands above the rest.SASRT has flying (not gliding) sections, boating (not underwater) and car racing.  The characters aren't as memorable if you're not a huge Sega afficionado but seeing some of these locations can only make a Nintendo fan pine for a Nintendo All-Stars Racing game.The best thing about this game is that the tracks change per lap.  One lap you'll be driving and the next lap the course may get blown up, causing you to fly!  It keeps every lap entertaining as you wait to see what happens next.  The items don't afect you as much as in Mario Kart so when you get hit, you don't get as frustrated.The only negatives?  There is no Crazy Taxi course and the game CAN be a little glitchy.  Definitely worth a try if you're getting tired of your new Mario Kart game but want something new.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												9/10, Far exceeded my expectationsI had been thinking about buying this game for a long time and I'm so glad that I did. It far outshines any other casual racing game I have played. Quick rundown of pros and cons:+ Beautiful game. Bright colors, tons of detail in the tracks, lots of stuff going on all the time.+ Controls are responsive and intuitive, fully customizeable+ Big selection of racers and tracks+ Drifting mechanics are top notch+ Car and plane feel perfect+ Racer mods add another dimension of depth to the game, allow you to pick a perfect racer for every scenario+ Game has a healthy level of challenge, accessible for all kinds of players- Capped at 60fps, looks pixelated at higher resolutions (I'm downsampling from 5K resolution on my 1440p monitor to fix this)- AI feels unfair at times, too perfect- Campaign mode can feel repetitive- Bumping other racers is wonky and seems to have random results- Jetski is too slippery and prone to oversteer- About 40% of the cast needs to be unlocked through campaign mode- Shortcuts are of questionable usefulnessOverall the game is incredibly fun and rewarding to play. Most tracks are set up so that you can boost almost continuously from start to finish. If you want to go fast, this is the game for you. Most of my gripes come from having to play through the campaign, where the random elements of the game paired with the perfect AI can cause you to lose races, and therefore waste your time. this can get frustrating quickly, especially in the later levels. Outside of that though, the game is astoundingly solid and one of the most fun games I've played in a long time.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
VERDICT: Buy Now (9.5/10) Completion Time: 10-12 hoursBottom Line: "It can stand up to just about any cart racer out there. Buy this ASAP."PROS+Tight controls+Constantly evolving races+Fantastic graphics+Tons of things to do+Replay value CONS-Expert difficulty-One bad courseREVIEWThis is the most fun I have had with a kart racer since Mario Kart 64. This is kart racing at its finest, where you will be driving, boating, and flying a huge cast of SEGA characters through courses that are constantly evolving.Let's start out with the gameplay. The controls are incredibly tight, and racing has never felt more smooth. Similar to Mario Kart, there are orbs scattered throughout the maps that give you special abilities, including shields, extra boosts, and weapons to use against enemies. Each character has their own unique "All-Star" move, where you will be taking on more powerful forms such as Golden Sonic to eliminate opponents. Boosts can be achieved by getting a perfect start, performing tricks while airborn, or executing drifts for a certain amount of time. Once you master drifting, racing becomes incredibly fast-paced, and not to mention fun!This game also looks amazing. The levels are huge, with awesome set pieces that you will most likely be interacting with at some point in the race. Most of the courses are bright and alive, and if you are in first place you will be able to see the track transform before your eyes. With every single race, the course changes before the circuit's conclusion, keeping you on your toes and making each contest much more dynamic. Finally, you will get a ton of mileage out of this game (It's a driving pun). There are four offline game modes to conquer, including a career mode, a grand prix mode, time trials, and single races. Career mode involves travelling through a series of events including races, challenges, and boss battles. Completing these events earns you stars that enable you to unlock new characters and advance to different events. Grand Prix mode has you completing four races, with the most successful racer earning the gold, and time trials and single races are pretty self-explanatory. I haven't even mentioned that there is an online mode yet. There is an online mode. There I said it. All of these game modes will keep you occupied for quite a while.I only have a couple complaints. Upon completing the hardest difficulty for the Grand Prix races, an "Expert" mode is unlocked which has an unbelievably high difficulty. I don't know if there is just something I haven't figured out yet, but boy do you need to be on your game to even make third. Also, there is one course that I simply did not enjoy at all. I found it incredibly frustrating with many tight corners and jumps that were more of a pain than fun. But these slight annoyances didn't detract from the bigger picture.I honestly think this is one of the best racers out there. It's beautiful, fun, and will keep you coming back for more. I think it can stand up to just about any kart racer out there (I'm looking at you, Mario). Buy this ASAP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												When you first look at Sonic all stars racing transformed, it seems like nothing more than a generic kart racer staring sonic.  However if you dig deep enough you'll find a much more complex racing system than in most other racing game.  First of all in addition to the karts you also have access to boats and planes for all characters.  This is where the games design shines as often you'll get multiple options of where to go, one where you take the high road in the skies and the other plodding on the ground or in a boat.  Another nice thing is the items which are only there to spice the game up rather than giving sucky players an unfair advantage.  Even the all star move is balanced in a way that it only really helps if you know how to use it.  The game looks amazing when running at max settings though I've noticed some significant issues with fps even when at minimal settings(Though this may just be my computer.  The game does have it's flaws, characters aren't varried that much especially since all star moves are so much more bland compared to the first game, and the leveling up system is dull and tedious beyond words.  Also I highly reccomend you play this using a controller only as playing with the mouse and keyboard sucks so much its not even worth trying.  But this is the definitive version of All stars transformed as it has additional characters with more promised while the console ports are left in the dust.  And since this game has gone on sale a couple of times since it's release there's little excuse not to pick it up.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Sega, a company who live mostly in our memories. When it comes to talking about our favorite Sega games, you'd be hard pressed to name one game that was released in the past decade. As a test, i asked a few of my friends on Steam what their favorite Sega game of all time is.My best friend said "Sonic 3", Streets Of Rage 2 was another game mentioned by a few of my Steam acquaintance as well as Shenmue, but nothing from the past 10 years.Just to give some insight into my history as a gamer, i grew up as a Nintendo gamer. My first console was an NES which i got for Christmas 1991, so it's fair to say, i was a Mario fan from day one.The playground debate over who is better out of Mario and Sonic was always a no brainer to me, because as much as i loved Sonic The Hedgehog (and i did), Super Mario 3 was the game that blew everything else away and completely obliterated the competition.Yes...you couldn't go far wrong with Mario. From 8 bit to 16 bit, from 16 bit to 64 bit, from 64 bit to 128 bit, Nintnedo always seemed to know what direction push Mario in, but with the success of 3D Mario games came similar attempts at 3D adventure games from other companies trying to achieve the same levels of success.Introducing Sonic Adventure, The Dreamcasts answer to Mario 64. The first thing i ever saw of Sonic Adventure was a screen shot in a games magazine, and it blew me away. The graphics looked phenominal and i remember thinking if Sega manages to transfer the same gameplay from 2D Sonic games into 3D, this might be a Mario 64 killer....but little did i know, it would be the start of Segas downfall.In present day 2016, attempts at recreating the Sonic franchise have been many. 3 Sonic Adventure games, Shadow The Hedgehog, Sonic Riders, Sonic And The Secret Rings, Sonic Rivals, Sonic And The Black Knight, Sonic Colours, Sonic Generations......the list goes on, and only sequels to the megadrive series of Sonic games captured a majority of peoples imaginations.With this in mind, I approach every Sonic game with an equal amount of skepticism and trepidation, but when i noticed Sonic & All Stars Racing Transformed in a Steam sale, my curiosity got the better of me...and i'm pleased to say, i'm glad it did.You may be wondering "why begin a review of a Sonic game with a whole spiel about Nintnedo", and this is why. Sonic & All Stars Racing Transformed is a Mario Kart killer!. Yes, despite the fact Mario Kart games are rated higher and have a wider fan base, i can't help but feel Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed fell victim to the sour taste left in peoples mouths whenever the name "Sonic" is mentioned. According to my Steam account, i have put 22 hours into Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed. In which time i have 100 percented it, something i never feel an incentive to do when playing a racing game, however, this game is so fun, i didnt want to leave any of it unexplored.Just to state a few reasons why i believe this game is a Mario Kart killer, firstly the track design. Where Mario Kart suffers from repetetive courses that stay the same, courses in Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed changed depending what lap you're on. The first lap might be land based on four wheels, 2nd lap on water and 3rd in the air. Your vehicle transforms to accomodate changes in terrain and is done automatically and with such fluidity that it dosnt distract from what is a consistently smooth exoerience throughout.The power ups are far more balanced and you don't often find yourself dropping from 1st place position to 8th in the blink of an eye just because someone decided to pull a blue shell from their back side.Those are just 2 points which i believe to be factually better than what Mario Kart offers. There are many more aspects of Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed which i prefer to Mario Kart, but these are all matters of preference that i don't feel the need to mention, mostly aesthetics and other opinion based aspects.To end this review, i'd just like to say i have over 150 games in my Steam library ranging from RTS to RPGs, from First Person Shooters to Point and Clicks, from Racing games to beat em ups, and Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is the most fun iv'e had thus far.95%

content:

												Awesome. 9/10Nostalgic & classic, yet also very competitive, challenging and has incorporated diverse styles of gameplay within the races. This game is controller friendly and fun for pretty much anybody wanting to have a casual jam session. Great for multiplayer/online gameplay.The different race tracks are beautifully structured and the classic iconic characters fit the themes of their cars so well. The interace has a really classic arcade layout but the frames are well polished. I love the graphics... I don't know how some people could complain about them. This isn't meant to be a realistic driving simulator, it's an SEGA-themed arcade racing game.The composition is a masterpiece. I love the textures and rich lighting that give the game a warm, vibrant and fast paced racing environment.I never thought I would find so much joy in what originally appeared to be too 'childish' for a grown man to play but the game is just awesome. I hope that other manly men with beards still feel manly after playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												A surprisingly coherent racing experience. The AI is genuinely challenging (and not in the typical racing rubberbanding kind of way) and playing online against others is legitimately fun, even when you lose. If you're a fan of Sega franchises and characters, you'll find that you'll likely have one or two characters you'll enjoy racing as. There's even a handful of third party characters that were all crossover promotions. The differences between the characters are all pretty subtle, and the modifications offer a great way to adjust your favorite character(s) to be more in line with your playstyle. Some of the picks for characters are odd (Danica Patrick?) and others are clever.The tracks themselves are interesting, all based on Sega franchises. Unsurprisingly, there's a ton of Sonic-related levels, but lots of other franchises get representation in stage form, as well.My only gripes with the game comes with the learning curve. You'll find that after two or three races, driving and boating sections will become second nature, and it'll take a few more races to learn tricks. The problem comes when you first encounter a track with flying elements. Probably the worst sections of the game, I dread when tracks are chosen that focus on flying because it's clearly the section of the game that was worked on the least, and should have been left out of the game. My guess was that they wanted to go for a Diddy Kong Racing dynamic with this one and couldn't leave flying out. It would have been a far, FAR better game without it.The other modes that aren't racing are half-baked at best and completely unenjoyable at worst. The game's engine is clearly not made for anything other than actual racing, and it shows when you play battle modes or Capture the Chao. You'll want to steer clear of those game modes completely and focus on just racing.Otherwise, the game is a coherent racing experience and is legitimately enjoyable. It's fast paced, and the weapons are fairly easy to utilize (though some require a bit of skill to use effectively). The sense of speed on some tracks is fairly exciting, and it's possible to boost almost constantly on a number of tracks, rewarding skilled players but offering a learning challenge to new players. Highly recommended to support this game in hopes of a sequel that removes the flying aspects.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Quick factsGood+ Solid port that runs well on many systems and looks good (tip downscale from 4k for better results if your hardware can handle it).+ Customize the stats of your driver to your liking with mods that you unlock just playing as them.+ Responsive controls that reward drifts and air tricks accordingly.+ Good soundtrack with tunes from some of Sega best games.+ Dificulty options for new players and experienced kart game players.+ Multiplayer local play with special mention to the option of the possibility to play the entire campaign cooperatively.+ Online multiplayer modes for up to 10 players per event.* Full Xbox 360 controller support with rumble.Bad- A little barren online community (nowadays)- Some bugs here and there (mostly in the track physics)- Generic items and some derivative courses.- Some form of balance issues.- Ommision of some other good franchises from Sega.One of the best "karting" games that exists on PC, and one of the select few that give the Mario Kart series a run for it´s money. The gameplay mechanics reward skill and dedication, even giving the players the options to choose his real favorite character and choosing determined stat presets to set it at their preferred style. The method of controlling your vehicle is a little loose, and the physics act a little wacky from time to time, something that can bother the way up to the podium in the S class difficulty. Also, the online mode doesn´t get many players nowadays, so it´s more likely you end playing only with your friendsGood variation of tracks from classic jewels from Sega like Panzer Dragoon or Burning Rangers, and   the soundtrack sports some great tunes from After Burner, Shinobi and more. Not as stellar as the soundtrack, the item selection is one of the most boring i have seen in a game, but well it´s not THAT broken, like the infamous Mario Kart blue shell. The game is well suited for new and veteran players alike, and more enjoyable with a controller. Solid choice for playing in local mode with splitscreen for up to 4 players.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
A great kart racing gameIt plays great. You feel a sense of speed and performing drifts and tricks is fun. I have a feeling that some of the people that worked on this game also worked on F-Zero GX. Compared to Mario Kart Wii, the cars control better. (I haven't played Mario Kart 8.)But it has some flaws. The menu has an very annoying announcer, the power-ups aren't that good and the music is not memorable. And although I did say it plays great, the physics can be weird sometimes and the track design questionable. Sometimes a small mistake can mean coming to a full stop and finishing the race close to last.This game can be hard. But in my opinion, that's what makes it great. And to add variety, you also race by airplane and by boat, with the tracks often transforming themselves, It will keep you on your toes.People will instinctively compare this game to Mario Kart. But it's closer to F-Zero and Diddy Kong Racing in terms of gameplay. And that's OK with me.If you're looking for a kart racing game to add to your Steam collection, this is the one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												This is a worthy successor of Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing. It improves on it and is currently the best competitor for Mario Kart. It may be a little inferior to the Nintendo kart racing, but it's still an awesome game for this genre. Plus, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed isn't a Nintendo exclusive. Like the title implies, this time around you race in 3 vehicle types: car, boat and plane. And you'll frequently change between these vehicles during the same race. The car plays almost the same as the original title, which focuses on gaining extra speed through drifting and boosting. The car is stable and easy to control. You can also drift and boost on boats and planes, but the boat sections are more focused on hitting ramps to perform stunts to earn boosts and the plane sections are more focused on hitting boost panels in a more straight line, while also evading the course obstacles to get extra boosts. The boat is harder to maneuver because of the water waves and because it's harder to turn. The plane is more straightforward, with the added verticality to control. But sometimes it can be a little stiff, especially during sharp turns. But overall, the vehicle switch mechanic is fluid and the physics are great for all of them. The carrer mode is essentially the same as the previous title. World tour to me felt like the original mission mode, but more organized with added unlockables. Gran prix is just that, a series of 4 races awarding points in each race based on the final position. But this time you can't restart in the middle of it, and that's how it should be to me. Time trials are the same, but this time with added leaderboards. And of course, there's single race. The game is also way harder than the original, and the expert difficulty is hard, with some events being very hard, like some of the time trial ghosts. But it's doable with some practice, and as you play and experiment you'll get better. There's also online mode, which isn't quite dead yet, but i didn't spent much time on it. The character and track selection is also better than the original. While some characters were removed, there's plenty of new ones. Some are from the same game as others, some from other SEGA titles, some 3rd party ones (e.g. Team Fortress), and even a real life rally racer that here drives a Hot-Wheels on land. This selection feels better and more diverse, even with the removed characters. The tracks are also cooler. There's only 16 tracks (not counting 4 returning ones), but they are more diverse, longer and change mid-race, so the 3 laps aren't always the same. Added with the vehicle switch and good design for the most part, these tracks are a blast to play on. They are also beautiful as well as the graphics, a real eye candy. The soundtrack is also cool. This time the tracks are arrangements instead of ripped songs, and they work pretty well (i love the Golden Axe arrangement on Adder's Lair, as well as this course). If you like kart racing games, this is an easy recommendation, even if you think that you may like it. It may take some time for beginners to get good, but it's definitely worth it.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Sonic : All Stars Racing Transformed is a fantastic take on the arcade racing genre boasting heaps of content and replay-abilty value as well as full controller support for those using game-pads.The maps are both visually and technically beautiful, equipped with dozens of tracks varying in difficultly from simple to advanced providing a user friendly experience for new players. The Transformation mechanics adding new layers to the game, providing the player with the responsibility of learning boat's, planes and cars all handling extremely different yet somehow remaining intuitive making the game that much more entertaining.The game is equipped with a single player career mode as well as a fully-fleshed out matchmaking system. Overall this game is a beautifully fresh take on arcade-racers and I have no doubt future games will be referencing it for years to come as the genre diversifies.

Fun little game and a nice addition to any cart racing fan's collection 8/10

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												This game... is awesome. ._.I really wanted to hate this game.  I waited for it to be cheap.  I even went to the local Wal_mart and played the Wii U version before even considering this version.  The Wii U version was a bit on the watered down side as far as I could tell, but the game went on sale a day later and even had cards.  For $7 or so, I felt it was worth a try if only to get the cards and waste time with my little brother.Then, I played the game.  For starters, the announcer is a bit annoying but really hypes the game up so you always feel excited, even when you shouldn't be.  The character roster is amazing.  I even get Team Fortress 2 and JSRF characters!  Not to mention, I went ahead and bought the Metal Sonic DLC character while it was on sale, and that is now my favorite character in the game.  Half the roster is still locked, but I should be able to unlock characters through world tour mode just by spending the stars I earn from each event.Overall, the game gets a 5/5 from me.  It is the closest thing to Mario Kart you can get without getting Mario Kart. Ha.  Seriously, though, it is a great game with great visuals, great characters and impressively deep gameplay.  There is a low bar to entry that should attract newbie racers, but the veterans can really sink their teeth into this.Now, I know it's not fair to not mention the negatives, so here are a few:1.  Announcer is absurdly annoying.2.  Autosave system scares me with a "progress will be lost" warning every time I exit the game, even if the game isn't going to lose any data.3.  Music is a little lame, and some characters would probably do better without vehicles.  Sonic, for example, can probably run faster than any of these cars move, his own car included, and no character really has any special gameplay mechanic.4.  Some of the early challenges are actually very challenging and may scare away new players.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Picked this up at a bargin under £5. I grew up playing the old Kart games especially on n64 so I was hoping this was a similar experience. Heard bad things about the original but this transformed version feels very complete. A strong Career mode with loads of unlockable characters. tracks and secrets. A very very high skill ceiling; the hard and expert difficulties are incredibly challenging and demand you master all the little tips and tricks you will discover while playing. The online community will eat you alive if you drop into matchmaking on first play. The game gives you incentive to unlock mods for your characters car as the more you use a certain racer the more mods you can use for that character. Racing, Battle mode, 1v1 elimination races, bonus style racing events (booster mode, rings and traffic mode are a nice take on the checkpoint style racing to mix things up)It has ran smooth for me at 60fps on highest settings, some really inventive tracks that nod back to mega drive/saturn/dreamcast days. (The house of the dead was my particular favourite.)It's pretty cheap and got a lot of replayability if you don't chuck the pad out of the window for some dirty scamp pipping you to a podium position with a well placed firework missile. Fuming.Enjoyed this one.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Quick, think of Mario Kart 7! Now replace Hang gliding with Jets and underwater with Boats. Now make it Sega themed. Put it on PC, and you got this game.It's a Mario Kart clone, like most cartoony racers, but it's actually an example of matching, if not surpassing, what it's cloning.Both the Jet and Boat control like you expect, and control well. The action is as fast as your skills allow. To get through the races, you need to master the 3 controls.As for the items, they are much more fair. Most notably, the "get the leader" item. In Mario Kart, there's the infamous Blue Shell. Don't pretend that it doesn't♥♥♥♥♥♥people off. Everyone talks about how the Blue Shell will home in at the leader, and ruin their winning streak. In this game, you have the swarm. A bunch of bees (or wasps, whatever), go in front of the leader. They can either dodge the swarm and keep going, or get hit and possibly lag behind. It can also get other players, but the major thing is, it can never hit the player who sent the swarm, so if they're right behind the leader, they don't screw themselves over. This may seem simple, but it's one example of balance. This makes things more fair.The tracks are truly eye candy and even change as players go through the tracks. Usually by lap 3. the course changes to a new transformation. This helps keeps things fresh within the same course.The characters are what you expect, Sonic and Sega. But the real catcher are characters like Wreck-It Ralph and TF2. The mix of characters in this game are really fun, and you have motivation to get the unlockables like Beat and NiGHTS.If there's anything to say about the AI, is that they will KICK YOUR♥♥♥♥♥ They don't screw around, and if you're not good at racers, you won't 100% this game. But when you start to get good, it's feels nice to feel rewarded with wins against the extremely tough AI.As for online, I don't use it much. But I hear there's lag, but it can be playable.If you're a Sega fan, get it. If you're a racing fan, get it. If you're both, GET IT! Even if it's not PC, get it on Wii U, PS3 (which is what I own), 360, Vita. It's a solid game. Altough I hear the 3DS version isn't the best.

Posted: December 6, 2013
												Want to see your graphics card do colours other than brown? Buy this game.Like kart racers? I'm pretty sure this is kart racer out of kart racer. It's not my genre of choice but once into the drifting, power-up-hogging groove it's good fun, with the usual random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ry of your competitors being balanced by your own opportunities and being able to mitigate many of the "unlucky" breaks with skill.It's a bit of a shame that they went to the effort of licensing, designing, modelling, texturing and voicing the bonus PC characters, to stop short of giving them transform animations and just use obscuring effects instead. The launcher where you set up keyboard controls is buggy and unpleasant. Neither of these things will cross your mind while charging through Adder's Lair to its outstanding soundtrack, or watching Rogue's Landing fall apart around you as an airship battle rages, or trying to corner through Burning Depths as a voice-in-your-ear operator warns you about the flooding track's changing routes. The game is made of bright, cheery, awesome.
