content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												This is a worthy successor of Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing. It improves on it and is currently the best competitor for Mario Kart. It may be a little inferior to the Nintendo kart racing, but it's still an awesome game for this genre. Plus, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed isn't a Nintendo exclusive. Like the title implies, this time around you race in 3 vehicle types: car, boat and plane. And you'll frequently change between these vehicles during the same race. The car plays almost the same as the original title, which focuses on gaining extra speed through drifting and boosting. The car is stable and easy to control. You can also drift and boost on boats and planes, but the boat sections are more focused on hitting ramps to perform stunts to earn boosts and the plane sections are more focused on hitting boost panels in a more straight line, while also evading the course obstacles to get extra boosts. The boat is harder to maneuver because of the water waves and because it's harder to turn. The plane is more straightforward, with the added verticality to control. But sometimes it can be a little stiff, especially during sharp turns. But overall, the vehicle switch mechanic is fluid and the physics are great for all of them. The carrer mode is essentially the same as the previous title. World tour to me felt like the original mission mode, but more organized with added unlockables. Gran prix is just that, a series of 4 races awarding points in each race based on the final position. But this time you can't restart in the middle of it, and that's how it should be to me. Time trials are the same, but this time with added leaderboards. And of course, there's single race. The game is also way harder than the original, and the expert difficulty is hard, with some events being very hard, like some of the time trial ghosts. But it's doable with some practice, and as you play and experiment you'll get better. There's also online mode, which isn't quite dead yet, but i didn't spent much time on it. The character and track selection is also better than the original. While some characters were removed, there's plenty of new ones. Some are from the same game as others, some from other SEGA titles, some 3rd party ones (e.g. Team Fortress), and even a real life rally racer that here drives a Hot-Wheels on land. This selection feels better and more diverse, even with the removed characters. The tracks are also cooler. There's only 16 tracks (not counting 4 returning ones), but they are more diverse, longer and change mid-race, so the 3 laps aren't always the same. Added with the vehicle switch and good design for the most part, these tracks are a blast to play on. They are also beautiful as well as the graphics, a real eye candy. The soundtrack is also cool. This time the tracks are arrangements instead of ripped songs, and they work pretty well (i love the Golden Axe arrangement on Adder's Lair, as well as this course). If you like kart racing games, this is an easy recommendation, even if you think that you may like it. It may take some time for beginners to get good, but it's definitely worth it.

												I picked this game up in a Humble Bundle. Seeing how most new sonic games are kind of bad now I didn't think it was going to be very good. It's a cart racer which I love cart racers. Mario Kart is by far the best in the category but if you dont want to spend the cash on a new  nintendo console this Sega themed cart racer will do the trick. It features Sonic and some of his buddies along with an All-Star cast of Sega characters. Including Crazy Taxi, Super Monkey Ball, Alex Kidd, and more. It even includes some of you favorite Team Fortress 2 characters! Like the Sega themed playable characters it also features sega themed courses to complete. The game features several modes to play in and you can even play with your buddies. The game is also fully compatable with Gamepads and the controls are easy to pick up and learn. Fun little game and a nice addition to any cart racing fan's collection 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												I don't know who'd not buy the game. It's amazing. And of course, has Sonic and all of your favorite characters!GENERAL:Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed gives you 3 ways to play; alone, with people from all around the world, and at private party. And there's even more ways to play when you play solo. Giving you alot of hours to play for your amusement!CONTENT:You got 30+ characters in this platform. Yes, 30 characters, including the DLC and the unlockable characters from your favorite titles: Sonic, Super Monkey Ball, and so much more! And you can play with them on over 40 tracks. That's alot of combinations there. And it dosen't stop there, you get 5 gamemodes to play with, the combinations are HUGE here.GAMEPLAY:The gameplay is divine. It's like SEGA learned from it's mistakes from SEGA All Stars Racing ancestor and remade it into a more original creation. It's nothing like Mario Kart at all, where you must get OP items to win. If you play alone, you can progress through the game, collect and upgrade your characters! And some singleplayer portions are difficult. It's mechanics are also great. Don't like playing alone? Play online and show the world what you're made of!WEAKNESSES AND CONCERNS:There are problems with this game though, no matter how good it is. First being is that to win, you have to rely on one mechanic: Powerful boostings at a rapid rate. You'll never have a decent Time Attack record without a powerful character. I.E. Shadow with Dreamcast mod is one of them. But if you're skilled, you shouldn't have alot of problems with that.Another concern about this is the server. Though the community is friendly, the servers you're gonna play in, will never be. As you're mixed with these new guys, and real MLG players, and some of them may have bad connection, causing an unbearable amount of crashing into walls and such. Even MLG players suffer from that.Yet another concern is the aftermath, and I mean what happens now when you beat the game, although I like this game, I, at one point, abandoned it because of how usual it is. But I returned to it in a few months after.One of my worries are also being about the tracks, although there's 42 tracks at most, the other 21 is  just mirrored.Last one is about one of the mechanics: The Casino. Chances are in a race, you could get a crappy thing, but a really good one is actually rare. I.E. The useless Nitro is often, but the best ones, like Titanium Frame or Stunt Nitro is almost impossible.FINAL THOUGHTS:To be honest, I love the game, it has alot of potential. But I wish that the developers could realise it. But then again, they might be working on something that could beat this. You should get it at full price, but if you take the problems seriously, then maybe at 20-40% off. I give it a 8.9/10

ProsThis game has tons of stuff to keep you busy withLots of different gametypes and eventsOn par, or even better than the Mario Kart seriesConsPersonally, I dislike the design of one track, especially on normal race eventsLack of tutorial. I had to look up on the internet for how to gain during and before the raceGraphicsThis game looks gorgeous. Overall very pretty and colorfulGameplayArcade racingTight and precise controlsFull controller support, which is great, even though the keyboard also works pretty goodEach racer has different stats, lots of playstyles to choose fromAudioCool soundtrack with lots of different tunesFinal ThoughtsHaving played many Mario Kart games, this was a huge surprise. This is THE PC Mario Kart. It can rival toe to toe with any Mario Kart game.The drifting reminded me of Playstation 2's Burnout games, which I loved, so I'm having a great time with this game. The controls while drifting are very responsive.Recommended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This is one of the best kart racers I've ever played.   I'm not a huge kart racing game fan, but I've played all the classics like Mario Kart 64, Diddy Kong Racing, and Double Dash.  This game is very much like combining all 3 of those games into one big package, while still mixing it up enough to have it's own feel.PROS-30+ Characters-Performance Customization for Karts-Several Gameplay Modes-Online & Local Multiplayer-Cheap DLCCONS-High Difficulty-GrindyGAMEPLAYYou transform your kart on the fly during races by going through transformation parts on the track, but you can also perform tricks that will give you a speed boost during transformations and also during any air time.  Go off a ramp, do a trick, get a boost.  If you fail the trick you will slow down.  Tricks are performed simply by flicking the Right Analog stick on the controller, and depending on the direction you will do different tricks.  Doing a certain trick at a specific moment can make or break your race.  E.G. Do a right flip, to move to the right in mid air so you can avoid a wall or a fall.There are several characters to choose from, each has their own strengths and weaknesses.  Sonic is one of the faster characters, but he has trouble turning while Amy has easy turns and acceleration but is not as fast.  You can also unlock up to 5 (6 total) mods for each character that will change up their stats.  Example, you can get a mod for Sonic that will lower his speed but increase his acceleration and turning.  This way you can play your favorite character on any track as long as you have the mod required for that character best suited for said track.  Mods are unlocked simply by playing your characters and leveling them up.  They earn experience for every race played, including in online matches.  There are lots of characters and this can actually feel like a grind but if you only play 1 or 2 characters it's fairly easy to max their level.  I haven't played very long but I have Sonic and Shadow both at max level.  The DLC characters automatically come at max level with all mods unlocked.There are several tracks to choose from, but most need to be unlocked in the campaign mode.  The campaign mode is a simple follow the path to unlock the next track.  You earn stars for each race you complete, and higher ranking races earn you more stars.  I recommend simply playing the highest rank at all times mostly because those stars are needed to progress.  You need to spend stars to unlock new characters, tracks, and certain mods.OVERALLAll in all, this game is great and if you are a Kart Racing fan you will definately want to pick this one up.  Don't bother getting the console version either since they are no longer supported by the devs.  PC version has more characters, tracks, and extra DLC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												You might dismiss Sonic and the Car Stars in: Transformation Trouble because of the similar ability in Mariokart 7 to travel by air and water, but the transformation mecahnic is wildly different - the different modes have different handling and speed and in fact you have to remember to employ a completely different set of skills. Pulling stunts off static jumps for boosts when driving is simple compared to doing the same off sudden waves in the water, and entirely different to barrel-roll dodging obstacles for "risk-boosts" in the air. Super Sonicokart Bros. Transposed is built more around such racing skills than lucky pickups, in every sudden drop and every shortcut and every level 3 drift opportunity.My complaints with Sonic & Friends Magical Racetime Adventure 2 are mostly aesthetic. The character's victory animations and voice clips are boring and irrelevant. There is dialog that has been recycled out of context from existing games, and anything new is poorly voiced and sounds to be written as if after a cursory glance at the respective Wikipedia article. This is all in stark contrast with the lovingly crafted vehicle and especially course designs - with their ambient action and easter eggs - as well as the clever selection of amazing reimagined music. It also bugs me that the pickups aren't themed around Sega games, in what is otherwise a consistently nostalgasmic package.A more substantial complaint is that the control configuration is seperate from the proper game, and you might even think the defaults are confusing.Sonic & Pals Friendly Fun Time Xtreem Death Race 3000 deserves much more recognition. The spectacular set pieces, scripted terrain transformations, and hidden surprises in every course (capably delivered by the amazing graphic detail) make each race feel like a trip to Disneyland, and the gameplay is equally exciting and beautiful for all the same reasons. I hear the PC version isn't a sloppy port, but the best version of the game, running at 60fps to the consoles' 30. Play this game right now or live forever in shame and sorrow, laying awake each night wondering "what could have been...?".You know what's even stranger than Sonic in a car? Sonic losing a track event in the Olympics. If you want Sonic to COMPETE he has to drive, so stop whining about that.

Example, you can get a mod for Sonic that will lower his speed but increase his acceleration and turning.  This way you can play your favorite character on any track as long as you have the mod required for that character best suited for said track.  Mods are unlocked simply by playing your characters and leveling them up.  They earn experience for every race played, including in online matches.  There are lots of characters and this can actually feel like a grind but if you only play 1 or 2 characters it's fairly easy to max their level.  I haven't played very long but I have Sonic and Shadow both at max level.  The DLC characters automatically come at max level with all mods unlocked.There are several tracks to choose from, but most need to be unlocked in the campaign mode.  The campaign mode is a simple follow the path to unlock the next track.  You earn stars for each race you complete, and higher ranking races earn you more stars.  I recommend simply playing the highest rank at all times mostly because those stars are needed to progress.  You need to spend stars to unlock new characters, tracks, and certain mods.OVERALLAll in all, this game is great and if you are a Kart Racing fan you will definately want to pick this one up.  Don't bother getting the console version either since they are no longer supported by the devs.  PC version has more characters, tracks, and extra DLC.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												When I picked this up during a Steam sale I really didn't expect much. However I was pleasantly surprised with SONIC & ALL-STARS RACING TRANSFORMED.This arcade racer is a comfortable blend of Diddy Kong's Racing with classic Mario Kart. The different transformation of vehicles, racecar, boat, and plane, all feel unique yet fun, and the transformations feel seamless.Multiplayer is definitely the best part of the game, but you can still get a lot of enjoyment out of single player. There's a large roster of racers to choose from, and, for the most part, the multiplayer works rather well.The only major complaint I have on the game is its strange hit detection: more noticeable in online multiplayer, weird things happen when you collide with a racer, whether you collided with them intentionally or not. Sometimes I'll fly off the edge of the track or the racer I hit with an item won't lose any speed. It can be frustrating in those moments where a single second might mean the difference in winning or losing.Even so, I've already gotten a lot of mileage out of this racer, and highly recommend that you and your friends pick up SONIC & ALL-STARS RACING TRANSFORMED

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Picked this up at a bargin under £5. I grew up playing the old Kart games especially on n64 so I was hoping this was a similar experience. Heard bad things about the original but this transformed version feels very complete. A strong Career mode with loads of unlockable characters. tracks and secrets. A very very high skill ceiling; the hard and expert difficulties are incredibly challenging and demand you master all the little tips and tricks you will discover while playing. The online community will eat you alive if you drop into matchmaking on first play. The game gives you incentive to unlock mods for your characters car as the more you use a certain racer the more mods you can use for that character. Racing, Battle mode, 1v1 elimination races, bonus style racing events (booster mode, rings and traffic mode are a nice take on the checkpoint style racing to mix things up)It has ran smooth for me at 60fps on highest settings, some really inventive tracks that nod back to mega drive/saturn/dreamcast days. (The house of the dead was my particular favourite.)It's pretty cheap and got a lot of replayability if you don't chuck the pad out of the window for some dirty scamp pipping you to a podium position with a well placed firework missile. Fuming.Enjoyed this one.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												Vroom, vroom, here we go! Mario Kart 7!Oops, wrong game and wrong company. Oh hey look, Sonic & SEGA All-Stars Racing Transformed!Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed (or SART for short) is the fourth installment in the Sonic & SEGA All-Stars series, which began with the mini-game based party game "Sega Super Stars". Obviously this game is a sequel to "Sonic and SEGA All-Stars Racing". This game was probably SEGA's response to Mario Kart 7, and they did a pretty good job of copying that game. It has the same 'transforming' concept of Mario Kart 7. In Mario Kart 7, you can turn into a glider, in this game you turn into a plane. In Mario Kart 7, you can turn into a submarine with wheels, in this game you turn into a boat. There are a lot of similarities between this game and Mario Kart 7, but I don't really care. This game does look a lot like a Mario Kart clone, but in all honesty, who gives a crap? This game may look like another Mario Kart clone, but it's a pretty dang good one.The gameplay is what you'd expect from a Mario Kart clone. Here's the entire Mario Kart-clone gameplay concept in a half-nutshell: drift to speed up, be a complete jerk with an overpowered power-up, give someone the Luigi Death Stare, boost like there's no tomorrow, win the race. That's pretty much it, but this game is special though, it's kind of hard to explain what makes this game special, but this game just is.All the characters and tracks are all widespread from different game series that SEGA owns, but in this PC version on Steam you get TF2 as a character, which is pretty cool. The only problem I have the character roster is that HATSUNE MIKU ISIN'T IN THIS GAME!!! WHY SEGA, WHY?!?!?! WE SIGNED THE PETITION BUT YOU WON'T HOLD UP YOUR END OF THE BARGAIN YOU DAMN GREEDY PIGS!!! DXIf you have played the grand prix mode or had to select one of the many cups in some other game mode, you'll notice something. Each prix (or cup) has 4 races, but each prix (or cup) has a pattern, here it is: The first, second, and third race has a track with only two of the three vehicle modes, the fourth race has a track where you transform into all 3 modes. Kind of interesting, huh?  So you only get one or two tracks in an entire cup where you turn into a boat, plane, and car all in the same race.Once you master the game, the AI is very easy to defeat. The AI is smart, but not smart enough. Even the S AI (the hardest AI) is easy once you get the hang of it.The World Tour mode is EXTREMELY demanding, the special mini-game races (or whatever they're called) in the game have you do the craziest of things, like in some parts the game makes you race THROUGH TRAFFIC. The most annoying thing about the racing mini-games during the World Tour mode is the frickin' time limit. So you're telling me I have to do all this crazy crap ON A TIME LIMIT?! Time limits are something that could tick off any gamer, but this game takes time limits WAY too far. Time limits in video games never make any sense, but this one takes the confusion and frustration to a whole new level with its dreadfully short time limits. It might take you forever to complete a special race due to the damn time limit.The time limits are not the only thing that makes this game annoying.  The other difficulty blunder in this game is the Time Attack mode. You know what these are, right? Get the best time than anyone else. Blah, blah, blah. Yeah, sure, but um...Time Attack is kind of.....impossible to beat. The Hard AI for the time attack mode is UNSTOPABLE. I've tried countless times to get S rank on one of the tracks but the damn ghost wins every time. Please, Sumo Studios, let me beat your ghost once, ONCE!!!This game also has multiplayer modes, but I've haven't actually played any of them. SRY DUDEZ! Well, that's about it for this game. I guess I can close this  book on this review and go back to my life. This review is done. DONE, next game, next, next one, NEXT REVIEW PLEASE.6.8/10I have one last thing to say before I end this review. SOMEBODY PLEASE MAKE A MOD TO PUT MIKU IN THE GAME, PLEASE!!!! OR SEGA, MAKE DLC THAT PUTS HER IN THE GAME, PLEASE DUDEZ!!!! Please SEGA, put our beloved Hatsune Miku in this game. Please......... T_T

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Fantastic game for fans of kart racers. It has quite a high learning curve and is deceptively difficult so don't go into this thinking this will be an easy game. Don't let that put you off though as it is very rewarding improving your racing skills. Every vehicle feels different. I tried getting a couple of my friends who are huge Mario Kart fans to play. They liked the feel of the cars but not of the other vehicles due to unfamiliarity. If you're not willing to give the game a chance due to reasons like that then you won't enjoy it. Stick with it though and you will find a beautiful, and enjoyable racing game and the best alternative to Mario Kart that you will find. The netcode has some problems which does lower enjoyment somewhat but the online matches are still the most enjoyable part of the game. Racing against other players is way more fun than racing the computer. Dare I say that if the game was more polished it may have even taken the Mario Kart crown! Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												A very fun racing game, the graphics are fantastic and the maps are really well designed, heres why.You do the first lap, short and simple.The second lap changes, a route might be blocked by a monster or something.The final lap goes ape sh*t.I have never seen this in any racing game before, well I kinda saw this in Spongebob Squarepants and the creature from the Krusty Krab, but the races feel staged and are very easy.However the game does have a downside, and that's with it's keyboard controls....Now before I tell what I think of the controls, nearly everyone is fully aware that Keyboards are better at shooting games rather then driving, however after some practice you can become very well.Now usually it's WASD to control the car or move the mouse to where you want to go, but here, SHIFT of all keys is to accelerate! Why shift? Why not the W key, plus to move it's the arrow keys. Again, why not WASD? I'm used to Saint's Row and GTA's driving controls and they are much better, why change it so SHIFT is accelerate and the arrow keys are turning? At least your hands are wide apart for room, but I would perfered WASD to this.Overall this game is fantastic, controls are strange at first, but it's a very fun game.Also playing as the Spy from TF2 in a plane is the greatist thing ever! OH NO!

content:
Posted: February 23
												When it comes to kart racers, this game is among the best. In a time where 4-player local multiplayer games are few and far between (especially on PC), this game really is a stand-out. If you're a fan of Mario Kart or Diddy Kong Racing, you will love this game.Pros:-Controls are fluid and responsive, and landing the perfect drift feels very satisfying.-Graphics are very nice, though not spectacular. Tracks, characters and vehicles are colourful and vibrant.-Great variety when it comes to tracks, characters and gameplay modes. 100% completion will keep you busy for days.-4-player splitscreen, with the game allowing for the use of nearly any USB controller (we even use N64 controllers)!Cons:-Some races are VERY hard on higher difficulty, to the point of feeling cheap. Pretty sure the bots cheat.-No option to disable bots or items in any mode, despite the first game in the series having these options.-Occasional weird collision physics with terrain in some tracks.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												I gave this game an unfair shake when I first played it as I thought it controlled weird and I didn't care for a fair amount of the characters and the ones I do care about didn't make the cut (Ristar, Streets of Rage characters, Alien Storm characters etc) but I went back again recently and I apologise for dismissing it so quickly.This game is really damn good, better than some Mario Karts I would say. It has more than enough to hold you over regarding single player content. There's your typical grand prix cups and single races but you also have an "adventure" mode where you do different challenges to unlock different things. Some people might not like this and would prefer everything unlocked from the start but this does give you more incentive to play. There's also local multiplayer (which I haven't tried) and online which runs very well. This game is about 3 years old and people are still playing. I'm managing to get into full lobbies. In regards to the port job, this is a port of the 360 version as always but with graphics options and it also runs really well. Some would say this is the best way to play it (much like Gens PC)The only complaints I have are this game did not want to recognise my XB1 controller until I reinstalled the game (you can also use a program called x360ce but it's incredibly fiddly) which is weird as it worked the first time with the controller and again, I personally can't care for many of the characters (The only ones I like are Sonic characters, JSR characters and BD Joe from Crazy Taxi) but that's entirely subjective.If you want a solid, fun kart racer and have no intention of buying a Nintendo console or dusting off a PS1 for CTR, this is easily a great alternative and in some cases, a better one.

												If you like Mario Karts, but don't like the hassle of finding your wii controllers, and LOVE the idea of playing multiplayer with your friends on your very own screen, then this is the game for you.One thing I will say, is that it does not like weird monitor resolutions; I have a 27" UltraWide monitor (2560x1080) and you won't even get to the menu, so I have to run the game in a more "traditional" resolution, but that's fine by me.On a positive note, my biggest problem with MK was that I never really knew where to go, but this game not only has MUCH larger indicators of upcoming turns but it also has brightly lit power-ups so you can see them ahead of time and plan your route accordingly.The inability to skip after-race-stats annoys me (I've been known to break things over inescapable cut-scenes) but I still had a blast with my daughter playing.So, plug in your spare 360 controller, load up and invite a friend. :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Being a very oldschool sonic fan, i went into this with very low expectations simply because sega seems to enjoy doing horrible things to their greatest intellectual properties. That being said, this is actually a really fun little spectacle racer (and probably the closest thing we will get to a pc version of mario kart.... though the game is distinctly different from mario kart despite drawing very obvious influences from that series. In short, i has its own identity that comes through very well during play while still paying homage to its roots).The weapons you can pick up all for the most part feel rather intuitive and easy to use, though i do wish there was better variety to the available pickups.It is also very much worth noting that this game has some incredible race tracks. All of the karts have 3 modes (car, speedboat, and stuntplane), and they modes are managed automatically by what is appropriate for each section of track. This allows for some amazing variety in tracks, and they all take influence from various sega games over the years (the track for After Burner is particularly fun).i would definitely recommend this game for any kart racing fan (or anybody who just wants a kart racer, they can be really fun, especially with other people), and if you can pick it up for a reasonable price i would recommend it even if you arent a huge kart racer fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2013
												This game is immensely entertaining. It's similar to Mario Kart, but as you level up the characters you unlock a lot of mods for your transforming vehicles to really customize how they handle. Using certain characters with certain mods gives strong advantages depending on which game mode and which map you're racing on. There's a lot of variety in the weapons, and you can use each in multiple ways. Game modes include typical kart racing with weapons, kart racing with no weapons, versus, sprint, drift challenge, boost challenge, ring race, battle royale deathmatch, and one where you have to blow up a giant tank without taking damage from fireballs and other obstacles. It's crazy.You start with a wide variety of characters and unlock many more as you play. Sega also adds new characters in updates pretty often. There are characters from Sonic games, Company of Heroes, Crazy Taxi, Football Manager, Nights into Dreams, Skies of Arcadia, Space Channel 5, Super Monkey Ball, Team Fortress 2, Total War, Wreck-It Ralph, and more. It's actually rather absurd how many different characters and vehicles there are! C class matches are a great way to learn the maps and controls. To win B class matches you need to start drifting. A class and Expert matches require a lot of fast thinking as you chain drifts with boosts and get to the shortcut routes. A class matches are very challenging for me. The online multiplayer community is full of dedicated, skilled Sonic fans, so even today there is no problem finding intense matches.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												At first I figured this would just be a bleh Mario Kart Clone, but after playing it for the last few days with friends, I've honestly come to the decision that it is arguably better than Mario Kart.Mario Kart loves to give the lower-placed players better items to 'equalize', including that oft-despised Blue Shell.  In this, the "Blue Shell" analogue is a swarm of bees.  The bees however do NOT guaranteed knock up the first place person.  They can dodge it if they pay attention/slow down, making it be less of a guaranteed "HAHA GO TO SECOND PLACE"  This single change on its own is a great improvement over Mario Kart.The stages are just about at the right length to be fun, not long enough to drag on (I've yet to run into any Rainbow Road race that takes 20+ minutes and is just soul-crushingly bland once the prettiness factor wears off).  Changing vehicles definitely makes it fun as they all handle differently.  For folks who don't care about weapon powerups, there is Boost Mode, where all powerups are just boosts.  No shooting other players, just rely on your own skill.The racers seem to be decently different, but there are ways to modify them after playing as them long enough to shift their stats a bit, so if someone takes your precious Sonic, you can take another character and mod their vehicle up to have equivalent stats to Sonic's, given enough time with that char.Overall, if you grew up with a Sega and love arcade-style racing games, give this a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Kind of impossible to not compare this to Mario Kart.Once you get past the questions "Why the hell is sonic in a car?", then you'll start having a great time.The rubber banding is almost no where to be seen, which is nice, I feel like I'm really owning some stages.The tracks are well designed and creative which helps to make the game feel fresh every time I want to have another 30 minute session. The local multiplayer is a god send, whenver I have a couple of friends over, we race it out to this fun game. The voice over (the guy who says "Get ready! Go!") can get a little too chatty sometimes which leads to small annoyances. The items system is similar to the Mario kart item system, however, it does have some different styles, such as a blowfish, ice attacks, and drones that follow the person in front of you.The delightful Car-Boat-Plane system reminds of Diddy Kong Racing, and the flying parts have some truly beautiful set pieces to race on.It's a great game, a worthy contender to the Mario Kart franchise. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												  If you like kart racers or fast paced arcade style racing games then this game is for you. In the golden days of quarters and pocket lint kids of all shapes, sizes and attitudes flocked to these ridiculous plastic racing chairs and dueled eachother in virtual races throwing all kinds of ridiculous objects at eachother. Easily the most memorable of these games is Mario Kart, yet this game does something that Mario Kart never did in all of its running. I enjoyed Mario Kart Wii, I loved Mario Kart 64. Yet in comparison to this game, it just doesn't hold a candle to it. This game tests your skill to quickly adapt, the tracks changes dramatically, giving new choke points and challenges to cut off and blast racers from multiple angles. This game practices a lot of the same things Mario Kart has, because its not broke so there's nothing to fix, but they adapt these things into the changes of the tracks flawlessly and it all feels perfect. I'm not the biggest fan of SEGA, except for a few of the non-sonic Dreamcast games. Yet, this game has a charm to it, that may very well make me like Sonic and all other SEGA icons.As a deathly loyal person to Nintendo (may not buy everything they make, but I do trust them as the last legitimate console makers in the world) This game has taken me over Mario Kart, and that says something.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												I was never into kart racing games. Even Mario Kart bored me a bit. Maybe I'm just biased against Mario, but this is a lot of fun. The car Transformations are fun, and the animations for them are neat to watch. Sadly, I noticed that a car often controls differently in it's various transformations, so a character that controlled well on the road suddenly feels more difficult to control as a boat or plane. Leveling your character by racing and gaining experience to unlock mods is another interesting feature I can't recall seeing in Mario Kart, and it's good for when your favorite character is lacking in their speed or handeling.The game certainly doesn't disappoint when it comes to aesthetics, either. The lighting and track designs are gorgeous,  and the vehicle designs are diverse in all of their forms.One that bothers me though, is the PC exclusive characters, especially TF2 and General Winter. Who thought these were good additions for a game like this? General Winter in particular just...doesn't fit in, visually.Speaking of not fitting in, Shadow is extremely out of character and it's kind of disturbing.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Great racing game, definitely worth every penny. You may think that this game is a rip off of Mario Kart, and you aren't exactly wrong, is it a bad thing that it's a rip off? Sumo Digital have got a game than many enjoy and refined it into a better game.. Sorta. It's only fun when you're good at it, otherwise it's just frustrating,+ Better than the first one+ More skill based, You can't just win because you got one good item... well.. most of the time..+ Good controls+ Wide variety of characters from loads of SEGA games+ 'Transforming' adds a fun new aspect to the game, makes it stand out from Mario Kart- Very frustrating when you start out, especially on harder difficulties. AI seem to only go for you.- Locked at 16:9 - No ingame graphics optionsNotes:Very few people play onlineSome of the achievements are stupid, I don't know three other people IRL who play this game. PC version is better than the console version, you can actually see infront of you and it runs at 60fps.Overall rating: 85/100

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Nice arcade racing game. Kinda reminds me of Asphalt 8 from iOS (stars for race completion, arcade drifting, boosters), but maybe all the arcade racings are like this, I haven't played them much.Played it on free weekend, maybe i'll buy it before the sale ends. Wouldn't buy it without the discount, though. The game is still repetitive and has primitive gameplay mechanics.I liked the leveldesign - bright, colorful and sort of psychedelic, loved the music and the character selection.Decent console port, except they haven't drawn the graphics for keyboard keys, so the key pictures in gameplay tips are still from the XBOX gamepad. You'll have to peek in configuration utility to see what keys you need to use.So pros - the game has nice look and feel, decent port from the console; cons - it's still simple arcade racing without any extra features (except for vehicle transformation, still not enough).I'll give it 7/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												As rather the opposite of a Sonic fan, I figured I'd try this game's predecessor, "Sonic and SEGA All-Stars Racing", and to my surprise it was a lot of fun.  It had a lot of similarities to the Mario Kart franchise, but it tweaked the things that didn't work and made it its own game, and I loved it.This game improves upon its previous iteration tremendously.  The execution of the vehicle transitions doesn't seem forced at all, and that along with the tracks actually changing and evolving during the course of each race makes each match an adventure that lasts just a few minutes.The weapons have changed greatly and no longer feel overly similar to standard Mario Kart fare.  Nearly everything is fresh and interesting, and the only guaranteed screw-yous have to be intentionally set up rather than simply fired.The controls are great, the online multiplayer works very well, and the characters are different enough to be easily recognizable at a glance.  Even the heads-up display is great.The only complaints that I have are that it's very graphically intensive, meaning that you'll likely have to drop your resolution a lot if you're running a fairly old video card; the announcer's trackside chatter is now practically gone; and new characters can only be unlocked in World Tour mode, rather than by simply playing the game and spending the resulting points.So yeah, while I do still rather dislike Sonic, I highly recommend this game for everyone who likes mascot racers.  It's a good deal at regular price, but if it ever goes on sale, JUMP ON THIS.  You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												I was never into kart racing games. Even Mario Kart bored me a bit. Maybe I'm just biased against Mario, but this is a lot of fun. The car Transformations are fun, and the animations for them are neat to watch. Sadly, I noticed that a car often controls differently in it's various transformations, so a character that controlled well on the road suddenly feels more difficult to control as a boat or plane. Leveling your character by racing and gaining experience to unlock mods is another interesting feature I can't recall seeing in Mario Kart, and it's good for when your favorite character is lacking in their speed or handeling.The game certainly doesn't disappoint when it comes to aesthetics, either. The lighting and track designs are gorgeous,  and the vehicle designs are diverse in all of their forms.One that bothers me though, is the PC exclusive characters, especially TF2 and General Winter. Who thought these were good additions for a game like this? General Winter in particular just...doesn't fit in, visually.Speaking of not fitting in, Shadow is extremely out of character and it's kind of disturbing.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
ReviewSonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is the new and improved follow up game to Sonic & SEGA All-Stars Racing. Transformed introduces online multiplayer, albeit a fairly buggy connection at times, a mode where you can play with friends in traditional racing or arena matches. Local split-screen mulitplayer is also an option for those that are interested.It's hard not to compare this game to Mario Kart, and Transformed is as close to Mario Kart as you can get on Steam (since you won't see any Nintendo games here). Transformed has the traditional Grand Prix, World Tour and Time Attack modes we are all accustomed with. Familiar item pickups are also present, including a sort of "Ultimate" move for each character. The animation, graphics, art style, gameplay and optimization are all extremely well done. and there isn't really a weak point to be found in this game.The karts are fairly customizable, and the driving mechanics are very fluid and polished. Drifting is smooth, allowing for extremely precise maneuverability. Transformed also employs water and air kart transformations in each level, changing up the style of the race, much like the newer Mario Karts. With so much similarity, it's hard not to like the game, assuming you liked Mario Kart at all. ScoreSonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is truly THE kart racer to get on Steam.Masterpiece- 10/10

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												A friend of mine suggested this game, I was dismissive at first of course, it's Sonic, it's a kids franchise. But having read other reviews and watched some gameplay videos (and also being 50% in the Summer Sale) we went in on the 4 pack and got it for a very cheap price (also bagging the Outrun DLC). All I can say is, what a superb, fun game. A mixture of Mario Kart and Diddy Kong Racing with a few other elements thrown in. Great graphics, well optimized engine (locked at 60fps), up to 10 players in online multiplayer. I don't think I've laughed and grinned so much since I played Super Mario Kart of the SNES back in the day and it brought me back to the days when I actually enjoyed playing for once. Highly recommended.

												A great racing/karting game. You get to play as many of the most famous SEGA characters including Ulala, Shogun, Nights and ofcourse Sonic & friends + some guest stars like Ralph from Wreck it Ralph movie or Team fortress dudes. But probably the most interesting and entertaining thing is the transformer-like nature of the cars which can transform to speedboats or jets depending on the situation on the track which usually changes with each lap so you end up running a pretty much different track in the last lap than you were running in the first one! In addition to racing you also get a lot of various challenges and unlockables and achievements so it's definitely worth buying. Don't be mislead by the fact it's a children friendly game, it gets very challenging on harder difficulties and in harder challenges.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Perhaps one of the best overall racing games that I've ever played, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is easily the best kart racing game that I've ever played. Mario Kart is commonly seen as the 'best' for this genre, but where as Mario Kart lets even the unskilled players win with last-place-powerups they get, Transformed instead still gives it's best powerups most commonly to the slowest racers, but makes them able to be dodged by the most skilled players. No Blue Shell stupidity here. The tracks are all fun to race around, and the transforming vehicles turn this from 'just a great racing game' to 'one of the best'.  The car, boat, and jet all control radically different, and are all fun. The tracks 'transform' as well, most of them changing every lap to accomidate more the whole 'transforming vehicles' thing. Every music track is a joy, wonderful remixes of classic Sega themes, and the tracks themselves follow a broad stretch of Sega franchises. Except Phantasy Star, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it, Sega.The online play is probably the best part, as the netcode works perfectly fine, and, last I tried, there was a pretty healthy community of players.  It's extremely unfortunate how many people avoid playing this gem simply because "I don't like Sonic." Anyone who even slightly likes this genre should love this game.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												This is probably the best Mario Kart / Crash Team Racing -like game on PC, no doubt, but it has so many flaws that I can't recommend it to competetive gamers. I'll break them into sections.GraphicsThe screenshots on the store page look kind of good, but even with max settings, the character models are horrible, maps are ugly and low res and it doesn't really have all that much of eyecandy like in the screenshots. Plus, more often than not, the maps glitch and sometimes essential objects are missing, like the track you're supposed to drive on. YMMV (your mileage may vary) though.Game ModesThis is actually the best part of the game, the offline content. It took me and my gf over 20 hours to play through the main mode 100%, before we moved to Grand Prix. Main reason why it took so long was probably that it wasn't quick to become good at this game and we never moved on to the next track unless we beat the last on the highest difficulty. This is also how I recommend playing the game, otherwise it's probably too easy. It doesn't matter which of the human players wins the race and that makes this game highly cooperative.Online MatchmakingI've only read that the skill rating is brutal and connection issues are everywhere, which makes your rating drop if you drop out of a match. I tried to play this game online, but never found a match, so in my case the online game is dead. Again, YMMV. I wouldn't buy this game to play online, unless you get a good deal for a 4 pack or something with your friends.DrivingThe most important aspect of any racing game is how the controls work or how the cars (and planes and boats) handle. In car mode, it's quite okay and highly rewarding to combo boosts to get faster. But this is also where the game falls flat. The stats that the cars have are way inbalanced. Pick one of the most overpowered characters (like Gum or Alex Kidd) and you have an easy game, even in the highest difficulty. But if you have a favorite character and it has multiple handicaps stat-wise, good luck. Some of the maps and A.I. require near god-like performance to beat, plus the A.I. cheats. I'll write more about A.I. later. Now, there are the plane and boat -modes too. Plane is okay, fastest of the three, but not really fun or challenging. You can air drift and try to cut corners, but otherwise this is the most boring of the modes. You can easily land shots even with the aim dependant weapons, the drones and wasps really f♥♥k the A.I. up in plane mode and it's just... boring. Plus some of the maps have invisible walls, so you need to take the long route even if you could easily just fly straight to your destination, because there are no obstacles. Not really annoying as it's so rare, but a "feature" none the less.Boats... God I hate boats. Turning with a boat feels like you're playing with a 200ms lag. Plus you often overdo it, because turning just a bit feels like it's doing nothing. Then you overcompensate it to the other direction and you're head first at a wall, losing precious seconds and getting last. You can learn how to play with boats, but that takes a bit of the character variety out of the game, because if you learn how to do it with one character, the next might perform differently. Plus some of the maps just have the most ridiculous unfun water parts that you'll just be glad when you've beaten the map.CharactersThere are a lot of characters in this game, didn't bother to count them, but unlocking them makes the offline modes rewarding. Now one of the biggest cons in this game is how the basic stats of some characters are just irreparably underpowered. High handling is mostly useless beyond level 3 and some of the characters have like lvl 4+ handling and that is compensated with a slower car. It's ok in Drift challenges and maybe Ring Races, but in regular Races it's a recipe for last place.If the first 2 stats (speed and acceleration) are low on the character, you might try to level them up and fix it with mods, but often it doesn't do enough. I understand that most of the variety in character comes from their stats, but it just makes some of the maps unforgivably hard in higher difficulties. Though, when you get better at the game, you can beat most maps with any character, like I did in my replay. I started over and only picked random characters for each race and didn't have problems. But sometimes you get Amigo for a Sprint race (beat the A.I.s best lap time) and you're in for a bad time. Overall, not a big con, any other game has better and worse characters, so it's just basic game design.Some of the characters are just annoying and badly mixed voicelines break the immersion. Don't get the Yogscast DLC or you'll hate him everytime you play against him. Shadow and Joe Musashi (?) speak with their radio voice and that doesn't really fit in the sound design. That's a small annoyance, but one nevertheless. And don't bother playing bad with A.G.E.S because he'll comment every crash and burn like it's your fault, which might be true but god, does he need to turn the knife in the wound? :DGlitchesThese need their own section. Bugs and glitches are so abundant in this game, that it's the main reason the game has turned into a swear-fest for me. It is just too frustrating having to restart a race over and over again, because either your character is prone to physics glitches (randomly getting flown up in the air, the car doesn't turn because it is considered being in the air etc.) or the map is glitchy. And none of these will ever be fixed for this version of the game. The last update was that Ryo character in 2014. So if you're getting this game, consider it glitchy from the get go. The maps are glitchy and the characters are glitchy. If you combine the two, you're in for a restart-fest. Otherwise you need to play the map all the way to the end and start again anyway. That is, if you want to unlock it all, like I do.A.I.In lower difficulties the A.I. is super easy and slow, but in the harder difficulties expect to get hit from all sides with all kinds of weapons that makes you lose precious seconds. It's in the game design, yeah, but the A.I. isn't really fair in the first place. It would be ok, if the A.I. was affected by the same bugs as you, but no. They get overpowered boosts, they fly through tricky and tight corners with ease and sometimes they get so far ahead it's impossible to catch up. Start button, restart, choose difficulty, smash A will become a mantra when playing this game. You'll restart so often for the tiniest reasons just because the A.I. does stuff you can't counterplay. Sometimes they target you as a group and that means you will want to restart, again and again.Map DesignMostly it's ok and fun, but the haunted house map is an example of annoying map design. 90 degree turns after a high jump? Doesn't really play well with the high speed feel of the game, having to slow down. Some maps have routes that are just super annoying and once you learn them you'll never go there again. Like the snowy map, you'll never want to go via the high route because it's one of the glitchiest parts of the map. Anyways, you'll have your favorites and pet peeves.ConclusionI don't know why I bothered to write such a long review for a 5€ game that is actually most of the time fun. The fun just gets undone if you don't get bored of the game before unlocking everything. The game becomes frustrating with all the issues and unfairness of the A.I. that will never be fixed. Without them, this would be near perfect kart racer for PC but we're left with an abandoned port that works with casual gamers. If Steam had other options than recommending a game, I'd happily give it something in between. With stars it would probably be something like 3/5.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Suppose i'll be the first to review in the open, i'm going to be a sport and say 4/5.It's a well presented game that is really well optimised.Real go getter for avid sonic fans, the soundtracks are very true so sonic of our spined friend's original days.Controls are a breeze, lovely colourful backgrounds and variation in gameplay that will keep you on you're toes, there's unlockables and achievements to be had based on player skill and lots of challenges for the player to attempt, a large selection of alternative game modes and above all else, it's fun.If you buy this one, i would have to say that if you don't quite get onboard with being hit with a rocket when you're in the lead, might be best going for another one, but as far as competive racing games go, i like it.Graphics : 4/5Great designs on maps although, visually nice to see, however, the wave textures are a little sloppy and at times they can interfere with control, though this is something that isn't that much of a problem.Sound : 4/5Decent, stereo sound tracks that display a little creativity on some original work of the previous sonic games, voice cast is those of familiar faces.Gameplay : 3/5Only discernable letdown is that there isn't an option for online grad prix modes, though there is plenty of room for exploration and a mountain of power-ups to gain the upper hand in races, help text is also shown between loading screens that will inform newcomers to a set weapon's function, over all a decently balanced expierience.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2013
												Finally... after all this time, a really, really, really decent Sonic game. Ok, maybe not in the traditional sense, but man, is this game fun ! There's a lot of variety in tracks, there are multiple routes to take, racers to level up, characters to unlock, stickers to collect and so much more. And then there's the transforming of your vehicle. You'll transform (next to your kart) into a plane and boat on the fly. It's a great idea and gives the game much more dynamic. It's the kart racer PC games always wanted (true, Blur was great too), no doubt.The graphics are colorful and sharp, the sounds are ok-ish, the music is very good and wow, the game actually supports my Xbox controller out of the box. I remember previous Sonic games having trouble with this.It also runs at 60FPS and never dips below. It's a great PC port for a great price.Only downside - and please note that it's only a small one - is this silly/annoying announcer, which Sega uses for pretty much all their own games. He sounds a bit corny in this day and age. And to be honest, I expected something better on that front.This game is just excellent and deservers your money if you're into arcade racers ! The campaign mode will also last you quite a while so you don't need any friends to have fun ;)Get it ![Rating: 87/100]

content:
Posted: March 7, 2013
												I got this as part of a Sonic Bundle from GreenManGaming, and its the game I have played the most so far from the list. Its one of the most addicting racing games I have played in a long time. Not to mention the inclusion of Team Fortress racer (Spy as plane, Heavy as boat, and Pyro as car) Shogun from Total War franchise and the manager from Football Manager franchise with the PC version. I was tempted to buy this game for the Wii U since I played the demo, and it was a blast. It was worth the wait to get the superior version of the game. The single player GP and World Tour modes have plenty of content to keep you busy for awhile, while the game's offline and online multiplayer capabilities make this an awesome one system racer, and fun game for all ages and players. This game may not seem like it would be worth buying, but it's SEGA, which have made many successful arcade racing games. With the popular IPs that SEGA has combined with their signature addictive racing gameplay, it makes for a fun and hectic time.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The game is beautiful, first of all. It is so colorful, and I enjoy playing it. However, there are things you must know before purchasing.1) You need a gamepad: Don't even think about playing this game with a keyboard and mouse. It is easy to configure the gamepad once you get to the configuration page OUTSIDE of the game.2) Glitchy: Some areas will count as off the road, even when you're on the road. Controlling the automobiles are a pain. 3) Read a guide: This game doesn't tell you about gaining boost during the start of the game, how to change directions while drifting, and anything else I forget. You have to read a guide if you want to get through the game. But the guides won't be long.4) Finish Grand Prix mode first: Dr. Robotnik is probably one of the easiest cars to maneuver, since it's so small and very fast. Unlock him to have him at your disposal during the mission mode.

Posted: May 19, 2014
												This is overall an amazing title. Quite possibly the best current gen kart racing game. The graphics are stunning, tracks are well made and not cliche. A healthy variety ofgame modes as well as unlockables to entice further gameplay. Splitscreen capablewhich is a plus. Only problem I've had is a few game crashes, but fortunately has onlybeen while loading, and NOT in a race. Breakdown: 7/10There was no tutorial, had to learn through trial and error. Also a few crashes. But a very solid hit. A game anyone can play and enjoy.EDIT (6/15/2014)S class difficulty can be more trouble than it's worth, it seems like the AI is scripted to harm you with weapons vs other AI, be it you are behind them or front. You are unable to make a single mistake if you wish to win on S class, not ot mention being hit by weapons over 3x can make it impossible to win unless you are able ot take a shortcut (not on every map) or get All-Star mode

content:
Posted: March 7, 2013
												I got this as part of a Sonic Bundle from GreenManGaming, and its the game I have played the most so far from the list. Its one of the most addicting racing games I have played in a long time. Not to mention the inclusion of Team Fortress racer (Spy as plane, Heavy as boat, and Pyro as car) Shogun from Total War franchise and the manager from Football Manager franchise with the PC version. I was tempted to buy this game for the Wii U since I played the demo, and it was a blast. It was worth the wait to get the superior version of the game. The single player GP and World Tour modes have plenty of content to keep you busy for awhile, while the game's offline and online multiplayer capabilities make this an awesome one system racer, and fun game for all ages and players. This game may not seem like it would be worth buying, but it's SEGA, which have made many successful arcade racing games. With the popular IPs that SEGA has combined with their signature addictive racing gameplay, it makes for a fun and hectic time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a damn fine kart racing game and definitely one of the best ones to come out. The controls are really good, the characters feel different from each other, there's little to no rubberbanding and the game feels like it offers enough event variety and reasons to keep playing. The music is also really good here. The weapon selection is also pretty good. There is no blue shell or warp orb equivalent in this game that would discourage the players from keeping the first place too long.The developer SUMO Digital really knew how to make a solid kart game. The tracks are well made, they play different and you really need to learn how to drift and boost to win in this game. Not knowing this some go online saying that the game is way too hard way too early. This is only true because the didn't learn the controls. Although the game does play faster than your average kart game because after all it does star Sonic. The game doesn't really get hard until later on when you start going for those expert rankings or if you plan to 100% the game. That's when the game really expects perfection from the player.Now on the down side the roster could've used some work. I actually wish this game could've been called Sega All-Stars rather than Sonic & All-Stars. The PC version has 27 characters with seven of them being from Sonic and the rest being from other Sega titles with a few exceptions. To me characters like Amy, Shadow and Knuckles felt like a bit too much of the same thing. Also there a few odd and out of place characters like Dana Patrick and Ralph. Also Ralph is really annoying with his lines in this game. Instead of the ones I mentioned I would've like to have seen characters like Billy Hatcher, Ryo Hazuki and Akira Yuki who are featured here, but aren't playable. Also it's a bit weird for an OutRun course to be DLC in a racing game. Not only that but the track is really underwhelming and you can't play it online. Other tracks do a lot better with their source material.But biggest problem with this game is how long it takes to start, end or restart anything. It's how the menus are made. It takes them too long to animate and you can't use them until the animation is finished. With a game as hard and fast paced as this being able to quickly restart a race should be a given. Also the announcer really shouldn't talk as much as he does in the menus. Also you can't leave the game open in a menu screen because every 30 seconds the announcer tells you to do something.But look past all the nitpicks you have the best kart game this generation.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Surprisingly enjoyable game with a wide selection of cars and good handling for keyboard gameplay.  The plane mode is slightly fiddly without analogue controls, but you can pick up a gamepad for <£5 but you're still getting the full experience cheaper than on console, and that's if you don't have a gamepad already.  There are very few games that I enjoy so much that I play them regularly for an extended period of time, and this is one of them.  Game is easy to learn, and hard to master.  Options for different classes and different stats on cars which cater to certain skill levels allows you to choose your own difficulty curve and rewards you for it.  Online, the game is fairly balanced, and every car and mod has a good use both on and offline.  The game actually has a competent rating system, which judging by the wierd numbers I seem to gain or lose every match is actually calculated based on quite a lot of things including the ratings of the other players.  I can't put my finger on why I love this game so much.  Is it the mechanical complexity that rewards skill?  The satisfaction of chaining together a level 6 boost and passing 3 people in the process?  The skillshots that belong in MLG montages?  Either way, a SEGA casual karting game frankly has no right to be good.  And it is good.  Really ♥♥♥♥ing good.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Sonic All Stars Racing Transformed may seem like a bit of a childish or bad game, due to the title - but do not be fooled. It is one of the best games I've played, and I will be sure to sink more hours into it.GAMEPLAY The gameplay in this game is crazy - you switch throughout levels to different cars, planes and boats. Remember, this happens in the same level; so you could have been driving one second, but the next, a piece of the cliff had fallen off and suddenly you're in the air, flying. Due to this, I will be splitting the next section of the review into different parts.CAR HANDLING The cars feel decent - not the best, but for an arcade racer, it does the job pretty well. I don't really have much to criticise, as all cars are different but there are no major flaws with the handling of the cars.  They feel mildly satisifying to drive, but I would say that the camera shake does make the game feel like it has frame drops.PLANE HANDLINGThe planes in this game are amazing. They feel so smooth, and refined that you will almost always look forward to the plane sections of a level. Mixed with the visuals, they provide a very nice touch to the game that I haven't seen before - although Mario Kart 7 + 8 does have similar sections, ala gliding. BOAT HANDLINGNot too shabby, I have to say. Boats can be tricky to get right, but this game has done a damn good job of it. It doesn't make you feel frustrated as the glide of the boats are easy to learn and also feel very light. In my opinion this is good, and it makes the transitions feel very nice as well. GRAPHICSThe graphics in this game are phenomenal - especially for a game with such a cartoonish atmosphere. It looks amazing at 1080p and I'm sure it will look even better at high resolutions - although on my 1080p monitor I couldn't get the game to run at 4K for some reason. Optimisation is decent, but I believe that the frame rate is locked to 60, which is a shame, especially for those of you with 144HZ monitors.LEVELSThe levels are well done, and feel amazingly detailed compared to what I've played recently. I can blow up parts of the map with powerups, and they will let me get to a shortcut or past an obstacle if I was about to crash, and that makes me smile as it truly feels like the developers have thought about their consumers.MODESI have not had a chance to delve into the multiplayer, but the Grand Prix mode is very nice, although the 3 laps can get a little boring. Still, I like that mode a lot more than the world tour mode. I feel like the World Tour could have been so much more, but that is just me. Single race is, well, a single race, and I believe the game has 4 player split screen - BUT don't quote me on that. OVERALLThis game is very nicely done, with lots of intricate details and decent optimisation. It's visuals are very pretty to look at, as well as it's cars and characters being detailed. The gameplay is a breath of fresh air from the pile of garbage that game developers seem to class as games these days. I would recommend it, especially on a sale. 8/10.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Wow. This game is really something special. I grew up on various kart racers, and this is so fresh yet so familiar. It is a joy to play on the bigscreen with a controller. On one hand, it is a cover of MarioKart, but yet on the other hand, it is very fresh and brings much more to the table. The problem with MarioKart is that it has not really aged all that well since the early 90's (IMO). Yes, it is still fun, but it needed to be overhauled - which is exactly what was done here.Pros:1. Wide range of difficulty from super easy to rage-quit-difficult.2. So many modes and tracks that the playtime hours stack up quickly.3. Awesome array of playable race characters ranging from Team Fortress to the Sonic Family and more.4. Tracks are video-game themed which is kick♥♥♥♥♥5. Graphics and sound are pretty great too.6. Meta-game character leveling up (something MarioKart should take notes on).7. There are still 3 laps, but usually in most tracks, each lap is different - your vehicle converts transformer-style into a boat, plane, and kart.Cons:1. The powerup concepts are borrowed heavily from MarioKart, yet are *slightly* underpowered. This meant that in MarioKart, it was anyones race pretty much up until the finish, which does not seem the case here. This basically translates to Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed requiring a bit more skill (if you will) to win any given race. This could be good or bad depending on how you look at it). I think I prefer the more random elements of MarioKart especially when playing with a group of friends with mixed skills/experience with Kart games.Overall, this game is totally worth full price in my opinion, and you certainly will not hear me say that often for a twenty dollar title.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I unfortunately can't get into Mario Kart anymore since the "Mario Party" design philosophy of handicaps and handouts has invaded the item system so thoroughly. But I am happy to find that Sonic All Stars Racing is a modern kart racer that maintains a lot of the things I loved about the Mario Kart games without all the Mario Party everybody-is-a-winner welfare gimmicks.Here is a list of comparisons that I think highlight which game is better than the other in which areas. You may or may not agree.Short version: Mario Kart destroys Sonic in charm, but Sonic is a better racer. Choose Mario for a more artistic, more cohesive, and more atmospheric racing experience. Choose Sonic if you want to actually enjoy driving.QUALITY OF TRACK AESTHETIC:Mario Kart 8 is the clear winner. Much more creative, vibrant, and fun-looking tracks.CUSTOMIZATION OPTIONS:Both games have some customization, but MK8 is better here, allowing you to choose your vehicle model and exchange individual parts. Sonic only allows you to choose "mods" which are just preset stat configurations but don't change your vehicle appearance in any way.CHARACTER/RACER QUALITY:Suffice to say, Nintendo has a much longer list of memorable characters with tremendous pedigree. Plus the characters in Mario Kart feel COHESIVE, which is to say they all FEEL LIKE they are part of the same universe and should be in the same game together. In comparison, the character options in Sonic All-Stars Racing are pretty underwhelming. The characters don't have the same pedigree, they have completely inconsistent art styles, and there is virtually no cohesion whatsoever--i.e. most of the characters don't feel like they should be in the same game together at all. It's just a random hodge-podge of characters from all over the place, many of which you may not have heard of and probably don't care about. It's weird that Sonic characters are racing next to Team Fortress 2 characters. Even weirder is when REAL race car drivers (e.g. Danica Patrick) start showing up. Just... a weird mix. But I love racing the classic Sonic characters.OPPONENTS USING ATTACK ITEMS THAT HOME IN ON YOU AND ARE IMPOSSIBLE TO SHAKE/AVOID:Mario Kart 8: There are multiple items like this and you get hit by them constantly (this is where a lot of the frustrating Mario Party-esque handicaps and handouts come from).Sonic: There are multiple items that have some degree of homing or aim-correction, but all homing attacks allow the *possibility* of avoiding them completely, e.g. by drifting around a sharp turn or around a solid object to make the incoming threat crash, or by firing your own attack items backward to neutralize the threat directly. Mario Kart used to be pretty good about letting skilled drivers pull off these types of exciting escapes, but more recent Mario Karts are more interested in handicapping skilled racers and giving welfare to less skilled racers. Sonic has a certain amount of balancing (as all racers do), but it still allows skilled racers to finish a race miles ahead of the competition if they are good enough.CAN SPEED BOOST BY PERFORMING STUNTS/TRICKS:Both games technically have this, but it is a lot more satisfying in Sonic. MK8 pretty much just has you press the jump/hop button to perform a standard trick, but in Sonic you can flick the right joystick to front flip, back flip, or barrel roll. And of course the barrel roll can also be used to avoid obstacles/attacks sometimes (especially during flying sections), which is always exciting.CAN SPEED BOOST BY DRIFTING:Both games allow you to do it, but the drifting feels better in Sonic. It just feels better to control. Also, even though the Sonic tracks aren't as charming as the MK tracks, they provide you with TONS more stunt and drift opportunities.SECRET SHORTCUTS & SIDEPATHSBoth games have these in equally satisfying amounts. That's in terms of quantity anyway. Bear in mind that Mario Kart tracks are more visually striking/creative, and the same goes here, but the Sonic tracks are not bad at all.VEHICLE TRANSFORMATIONS:Both games have the racers travel over all kinds of terrain: land, water, and air. But in Mario Kart it's mostly just terrain. In Sonic, your vehicle actually literally transforms between car, boat, and plane. Each of these forms of your vehicle controls completely differently and has to contend with completely different physics. The boat racing in particular can be very challenging--especially when racing across choppy water full of whirlpools and huge waves, etc. Sonic also has much more exciting flying sections, IMO. Lots of fly-through opportunities for daring flyers. And dat barrel roll.TRANSFORMING TRACKS:Sonic wins here. The tracks themselves transform as you race on them. There are a few tracks that are static through the whole race, but many tracks will change in some way. Either part of the track will get destroyed and then you'll drive off the end and transform into a plane, or a huge spaceship will land on the track, forcing all racers to drive inside/through it, and other such transformations. Some transformations are cooler than others, but the good ones are very fun.EMPHASIS ON COMBOS:Here is where Sonic really shines. Both Sonic and Mario Kart force you to use boosting if you want to stand any sort of chance against more advanced racers. However, I think Sonic does a better job of stringing together long chains of boost and stunt opportunities, letting you set up a huge combo chains. Since there are more types of stunts, mid-race vehicle transformations, and mid-race changes in the track itself, these combo chains can be very exciting. Sonic also makes it possible for you to FAIL your stunts if you execute them at the wrong time, so there is always an element of tension when you've got a good combo going. If you are a really good racer in Sonic, you can sometimes boost almost non-stop through an entire race.MINI-GAMES ETC:Mario Kart used to have battle mode, which was a huge selling point. For some reason they decided to get rid of it. Mario Kart 8 doesn't really have much in the way of other activities as a result, which is too bad.Sonic All-Stars Racing also does not have a battle mode, but if you select "world tour", there are some other racing activities you can do, such as drifting challenges and boosting challenges. I am personally a big fan of the TRAFFIC challenges, which fills one of the game's tracks with hundreds of other cars and tasks you with making good time while avoiding any crashes. (There are even police cars that try to ram directly into you!) Mario Kart would have posed a huge challenge if it still had battle mode, but with the absence of battle mode, Sonic's other driving activities win here.RUBBER BANDING:All racing games do it. MK8 and Sonic both do it. But I have to admit, even though Sonic is not as cheap as MK8 with items, it can be VERY cheap with the rubber banding on the A class races.OVERALL:Mario Kart has established itself as a kart racer that puts all racers on relatively equal ground, regardless of skill level. This is great for a group of friends with relatively equal skill level, but can be frustrating or even infuriating for skilled players who are held back by all of the constant handicaps.Sonic is not as good as Mario Kart in a number of ways, but it manages to be a fun kart racer that is very similar to Mario Kart, but it has more to offer players who want to win on account of driving skill and who are growing weary of Mario Kart's penchant for handicaps and handouts.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is racing at its finest-- its absolute finest. One could even say it surpasses Mario Kart! The game looks stunning and preforms almost completely without flaw. The characters are well balanced even if stats say otherwise. As an example, B.D. Joe has a high speed advantage, yet Amigo has a major speed disadvantage, but his acceleration and boost can bring him to first place if you know what to do. The tracks are filled with sega references and fill an old-school sega nerd's heart with joy. They're all fair and fun to race through on the ground, in the water, or even in the air. Whether you play alone or with friends-- it's all fun regardless. There are tons of missions to play through on easy, medium, or hard difficulties. Once you beat the game, you unlock an expert difficulty to really challenge yourself again! The game doesn't dry up fast at all; it's constantly keeping you racing. It doesn't matter if you're pro Nintendo or pro Sega, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is undeniably the best racing game to date.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Oh, where to begin with this game? Oh, I know; it's brilliant! While the model quality for most characters is rather poor (I'm looking at you, Sonic and Ralph) and the stock clips can be irrelevant a lot of the time, the true appeal in this game lies where it matters; the game play, especially in online mode. For hours on end you will find yourself racing head to head with up to ten friends, which can become highly competitive and addicting on many an occassion. Unlike the recent Mario Kart installments, your online race won't be ruined by an item similar to a spiny blue winged ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Instead, the items are fairly balanced (though I'd like to see a way to build up the All Star in future games) and the only item you can find yourself really getting frustrated at is the triple ice shot as it freezes you on contact. If you can live with mediaocre stock clips and alright character models (the environments themselves are overwhelming), I'd highly recommend this game on its online value alone.
